 BANGLADESH COASTAL EMBANKMENT REHABILITATION PROJECT I. PROJECT AND SECTOR BACKGROUND A. Project Background 1.1 Natural calamities are a recurring phenomenon in Bangladesh. The most severe occur in the form of cyclonic storms which affect the coastal districts. The country has over 700 km of coastline on the mainland and several offshore islands in the Bay of Bengal. Vulnerable areas include the important port towns of Chittagong and Khulna, and the heavily populated islands of Sandwip, Kutubdiya and Hatiya. During the last 125 years, over 42 cyclones hit the coastal belt; 14 occurred during the last 25 years. Cyclones often cause major destruction of human life, livestock, crops, properties, and physical infrastructure. Such cyclones also tax the country's institutional and financial capabilities, since resources have to be diverted to provide immediate relief to the affected population and to restore damaged or destroyed physical facilities. 1.2 Recent cyclones causing widespread devastation and loss of life occurred in November 1970, May 1985, November 1988, and April 1991. After the cyclone of November 1970, the Government of Bangladesh (GOB), assisted by IDA under the Coastal Area Rehabilitation Project (Cr. 339-BD) and other donors, initiated a reconstruction program aimed at (a) rehabilitation of the economy of the affected areas, and (b) provision of protection from future cyclones. The benefits of these investments were demonstrated during the cyclone of May 1985. For example, the coastal embankment withstood the tidal surge at the peak period and although the embankment was overtopped or breached in several places, the energy of the tidal surge was dissipated and, by and large, houses remained in site. The radio system also worked satisfactorily and conveyed warnings of the advent of the cyclone, and the cyclone shelters and other facilities were used effectively. Due to these improvements, loss of life and damage to infrastructure were relatively limited. However, destruction was almost total on the unembanked islands and the newly accreted parts of the mainland where most people, with their houses and livestock, were swept away by the tidal wave. By the time of the April 1991 cyclone, the embankments were in a poor state of maintenance, and were breached in many locations. The cyclone caused about 140,000 deaths, and severe damage throughout the eastern coast of the Bay of Bengal. Had the embankments been in better condition, the damage would have been much less severe. 1.3 In 1986 GOB formulated a National Cyclone Protection Program including proposed programs for improving the existing coastal embankment; protecting newly accreted lands; developing forests; improving telecommunications, roads and coastal transport; and providing improved and less costly cyclone shelters, to be used also as schools and health facilities. Improvements to the coastal embankments and protection of newly accreted land were to be undertaken in two phases. The mid-term program would strengthen existing coastal embankments, while the long-term program would include the construction of embankments and associated structures for the
 protection of newly accreted lands. After various delays, caused in part by the 1987 and 1988 floods, a contract was signed with consultants (a joint venture led by KAMPSAX International) financed by the European Community (EC), which included provision for preparation of the mid-term program and developing TOR for a study of the long-term program. 1.4 The consultants' studies were in progress when the April 1991 cyclone struck. At GOB's request, the World Bank agreed to coordinate donor assistance. The Government also requested the consultants to prepare plans and designs for a Priority Works Program (PWP) to provide for the most urgently needed embankment repair and rehabilitation work. Meanwhile, the World Food Programme (WFP) financed earthworks to provide temporary protection until the full embankments can be constructed. Funding was arranged from Saudi Arabia (about US$13.3 million equivalent), a Japanese grant (about US$23 million equivalent, under IDA administration), EC (about US$4 million), and US$29 million from amendments to IDA credits 1467, 1784, 1870, and 2048, for a program including about 135 km of embankment rehabilitation and about 55 km of new retired embankments. Work has been substantially completed except for one polder where there were objections to the planned alignment, and a second where additional drainage improvements have been found necessary. A new alignment has now been agreed and about $3 million equivalent for completion of the work for the two polders is proposed for financing under this proposed credit. 1.5 Following the April 1991 cyclone, there was increased recognition that reliable protection of human lives can be provided at the most economic cost through a program of construction of additional cyclone shelters combined with establishment of an appropriate cyclone disaster preparedness system. Proposals for such a project are being prepared separately for consideration in FY97. A component to improve road access to facilitate post-cyclone relief operations, originally proposed as part of this project, is now being financed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The proposed cyclone embankment rehabilitation works under this project would complement the above efforts by providing partial protection of crops and infrastructure, as well as additional protection of human lives even after the construction of an appropriate number of shelters. Even in areas of adequate shelters, a portion of the population does not leave their homes (since most cyclones do not turn out to be severe and leaving home risks theft of possessions). Moreover, embankments provide inhabitants more time to reach shelters safely. 1.6 While the project was originally planned primarily in terms of cyclone protection, it has important benefits in increasing agricultural production, through protecting coastal agricultural areas from saline inundation during normal annual monsoons and improved cropping patterns due to reduced cyclone risks, and better drainage. Most of the proposed project works would be economically viable on the basis of such increases in agricultural production, even without the benefits of the project in reducing cyclone damages and saving lives.
 B. The Agriculture Sector The Setting and Recent Trends 1.7 Agriculture, consisting of crops, fisheries, livestock, and forestry subsectors, is still the predominant sector of Bangladesh's economy. Its relative share of GDP, even though on a declining trend, remains high. The share has fallen from about 53% in FY73 to 43% in FY83 and to 36% in FY92 (at constant 1984/85 prices). Processed and unprocessed agricultural products, though also declining in relative importance, account for about 32% of the country's export earnings. Agriculture also has significant forward and backward linkages with other sectors. It supplies raw materials for the most important single manufacturing subsector, jute, and for smaller industries like food processing, tobacco manufacturing, leather tanning, and pulp and paper. It is the market for the growing fertilizer industry. Trade and transport of agricultural goods and inputs account for a large percentage of these sectors' contribution to GDP. Agriculture employs over 60* of the country's civilian population, provides the principal livelihood for most of the poor. 1.8 The sector is dominated by the crop subsector, especially rice. Crop production accounts for almost 70% of the value of agricultural output while fisheries, livestock, and forestry each account for about 10%. The share of foodgrains in the value of agricultural output is about 50%. Within the foodgrains, rice accounts for about 90% of the value of output while wheat accounts for 6%. 1.9 Overall, growth in agricultural production slowed in the 1970s due to war, floods, drought, and inappropriate policy decisions. Growth increased moderately in the early 1980s. There was a substantial upsurge in growth in the late 1980s, based on trends in irrigation and fertilizer usage, which were not immediately visible in increased crop production due to severe floods in FY88 and FY89. Based upon these underlying trends, crop production jumped by 9W in FY90. Rice production, which had been growing at about 2% per annum between FY61 and FY89, increased by almost 15% between FY89 and FY90. Policy reforms involving privatization of the distribution of fertilizer and minor irrigation equipment and resulting in rapid expansion of minor irrigation (permitting multicropping and growing high yielding variety rice in the dry season) accounted for the jump in rice production. However, this led to unprecedented declines in rice prices leading to reduced incentives for further rapid expansion. During the period FY90 through FY93 crop production grew at only slightly more than 1% per year. The fisheries subsector, in contrast, has been growing at over 6% per year during the 1990s. 1.10 As a result of the acceleration in rice production, Bangladesh, which had long been dependent upon food aid to meet minimal foodgrain requirements, achieved rice self-sufficiency in years of normal weather and even began to export small quantities of rice. (In years of poor weather such as FY94/95, shortages of rice still occur.) If Bangladesh is to continue to expand agricultural production and take advantage of opportunities for expansion of low-cost irrigation, it must begin to diversify production (including export quality rice as well as other crops.) This requires the
 spread of knowledge of appropriate production methods, through improved effectiveness of research and extension (both public and private sector). Nevertheless, some expansion of rice production in line with Bangladesh's comparative advantage will still be required to meet the needs of the growing population. Aaricultural Development Obiectives and Strateav 1.11 In light of the country's heavy dependence on food aid, GOB's main objective for agriculture since independence has been to achieve food security through a policy of food self-sufficiency, the latter being interpreted largely as a drive to achieve self-sufficiency in the production of rice, the staple foodgrain. GOB has set two major goals for the agriculture sector in the current Five-Year Plan (FY91-95): (a) attaining foodgrain (rice) self-sufficiency by the end of the plan period; and (b) increasing the production of minor but nutritionally important crops to improve the quality of food consumption. Attainment of these objectives would also reduce poverty. 1.12 Since independence, the primary emphasis of development efforts in agriculture has been to replace the traditional cultivation methods, characterized by low and sharply fluctuating yields, by more modern techniques leading to higher production and sustained growth. The poor performance of the sector was identified with the low level of technology characterizing traditional agriculture and overwhelming dependence on weather. A breakthrough in agriculture was considered primarily dependent on a strategy of a rapid expansion of irrigation-fertilizer-seed technology. The current Five-Year Plan articulates a strategy for achieving more rapid agricultural growth, emphasizing the need to shift from high risk, monsoon-dependent production to lower risk, irrigated production. This is to be achieved primarily through expanding minor irrigation coverage, stimulating crop diversification, relying more on competitive markets for input supply to farmers, improving rural transport infrastructure, strengthening agricultural research and extension systems to develop new technologies and diffuse the proven technologies to farmers, making adequate credit available to finance needed investments, and improving the macroeconomic policy environment. 1.13 The strategy for the sector, as spelled out in the current Five- Year Plan, is basically consistent with the consensus arising from intensive dialogue within GOB and between GOB and donor agencies in general, and IDA, the Asian Development Bank, the European Community, the Overseas Development Administration of the U.K., and the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), in particular. The dialogue has been based on the findings of sector work that has been carried out by IDA and other donors. It has been demonstrated that minor irrigation equipment (shallow tubewells, deep tubewells, and low lift pumps) has to be the method of choice for expanded irrigation on grounds of cost per irrigated hectare, ease of management, minimum reliance on public resources, and affordability by farmers. Expansion of minor irrigation is also the only alternative that would bring quick increases in production over the short and medium term. Moreover, the strategy would not be constrained by availability of irrigable land and water during this decade. GOB, with donor support, is therefore pursuing private
 - 5 - sector-led minor irrigation expansion as the main pillar of its agricultural development strategy for this decade. As part of this strategy, it aims to liberalize further the trade and regulatory framework for agricultural inputs with a view to allowing a major role for market forces and private initiatives. While a lot has been achieved with respect to agricultural policy reforms, further action is needed to: (a) remove remaining policy bottlenecks (e.g., formal legal actions to make recent reforms in seed policy and deregulation of foodgrain marketing permanent are needed to give the private sector confidence to invest in these fields); (b) make the agricultural credit system work; and (c) improve weak project administration and the poor implementation record. 1.14 The overall strategy has been fairly successful. However, the progress made in the sector has been almost totally the result of increased irrigation. Average yields per hectare per season for irrigated and non- irrigated production have not increased, indicating the need for increased attention to improving agricultural extension and research programs. The increase in rice production means that Bangladesh may soon have a new problem of dealing with surplus rice in years of good weather. This requires a substantial change in the thinking of the Government and the donor community, with increased emphasis either on policies for encouraging crop diversification or for the possibly more difficult task of improving a portion of the crop to exportable quality. Nevertheless, given continued rapid population growth (which has been reduced somewhat to 2.2t per annum) and severe shortage of cultivable land, Bangladesh must continue substantial efforts to accelerate agricultural growth to keep ahead of the population growth. Moreover, with 601 of the labor force still engaged in agriculture, any strategy for economic growth and poverty alleviation must include continued increases in the productivity of the agricultural sector. C. IDA's Involvement in Agricultural DeveloDment 1.15 IDA has been involved in Bangladesh's agricultural sector for many years. The involvement has been in the form of lending operations, sector work and special studies, policy dialogue, and coordination of donor activities in the sector. The lending program for Bangladesh has emphasized agriculture, especially deve] )ing water resources, strengthening agricultural support services, and developing complementary infrastructure. Sector work and special studies have been used by IDA as the basis for the lending program and policy dialogue with GOB. IDA has also been working closely with the aid community to encourage consistency of approach and avoid duplication of effort. 1.16 Consistent with GOB's priorities, increased food production, especially rice, has been the main target of IDA's lending in agriculture with emphasis given to minor irrigation development and flood control and drainage. IDA is also assisting in the exploitation of the yet unexploited potential that Bangladesh has in the fisheries subsector. Given that fuel shortage and population pressure are encouraging encroachment on forests, IDA is also playing an important role in preserving forests through its lending program, e.g., financing agro-forestry activities. In addition, IDA is financing
 - 6 - support services (e.g., research and extension) and technical assistance (e.g., in flood control). Ongoing IDA-supported agricultural projects include: Small Scale Flood Control, Drainage and Irrigation II (Cr. 1870-BD), BWDB Systems Rehabilitation (Cr. 2099-BD), Third Fisheries (Cr. 2146-BD), Agricultural Support Services (Cr. 2233-BD), National Minor Irrigation Development (Cr. 2246-BD), and Forest Resources Management (Cr. 2397-BD). A major theme in Bangladesh's agenda for encouraging sector development is expansion of private sector services to enhance efficiency. IDA has used its lending program to promote policy reforms in this direction. For example, in close collaboration with the Asian Development Bank, IDA assisted GOB in 1991 to develop a list of investments and input requirements linked to an action program for policy and institutional reforms. IDA supported this package through three projects: Shallow Tubewells and Low Lift Pumps (Cr. 2253-BD, now closed), National Minor Irrigation Development and Agricultural Support Services. IDA has also been coordinating an international effort aimed at formulating a plan to improve Bangladesh's ability to deal with flood hazards. This included coordinating the work of a panel of experts assigned to oversee the implementation of a series of studies and pilot projects which will recommend an appropriate Flood Action Plan (FAP). As this work draws to a close at the end of 1995, IDA is assisting GOB in developing permanent institutions for improved water sector planning, preserving the institutional capacity developed under FAP and making multi-disciplinary planning approaches part of Bangladesh's normal water sector planning procedures. 1.17 The proposed project is part of IDA's efforts to improve Bangladesh's ability to deal with flood hazards, but reflects the unique characteristics of the project area. The problems of saline intrusion affect only a small portion of the country, and the opportunities for similar yield increases through keeping out saline water are limited. The high rates of return available for certain project investments also reflect the inherent advantages of a rehabilitation project, able to take advantage of the sunk costs of prior investments. However, the opportunities for similar coastal embankments to protect newly accreted lands are well worth studying as part of the longer term post-FAP water sector planning activities described above. While the proposed project as a whole can be justified based upon its quantifiable agricultural production benefits, there are significant non- quantifiable benefits in the savings of human lives during future cyclones. Therefore, this project should not be considered solely in terms of IDA's agricultural sector strategy. D. Institutions Involved in the Prolect 1.18 Two institutions, Bangladesh Water Development Board (BWDB) and Forest Department (FD), are involved in the preparation and implementation of the project. Bangladesh Water DeveloDment Board 1.19 BWDB was established in 1972, when the former East Pakistan Water and Power Development Authority (EPWAPDA) was reorganized into two separate agencies -- the BWDB and the Power Development Board (PDB). Under the
 - 7 - supervision of the Ministry of Water Resources (MOWR), BWDB's mandate is to plan, construct, operate and maintain projects for surface water irrigation, flood control, and drainage, including town protection and river training, throughout the country. It is also responsible for operating and maintaining about 400 completed projects ranging in size from small single-structure schemes to large multipurpose flood control, drainage, and irrigation projects. Its main sources of funding are: (a) GOB's Development Budget for the construction of new projects and rehabilitation of a large number of existing schemes; (b) the Revenue Budget for operation and maintenance (O&M) of completed projects (including an allocation for debt service, taxes and arrears); and (c) the Food for Work Programme (FFW) with an allocation of wheat utilized for the repair and maintenance of existing projects, and for the construction of new schemes. Since 1972 IDA has supported BWDB's program with 15 credits, totalling about US$440 million for 11 new projects and four flood rehabilitation operations. 1.20 BWDB is managed by a six member Board comprising a Chairman, and five Members for Planning, Implementation, Operation and Maintenance (O&M), Administration, and Finance, respectively. The headquarters organization is primarily responsible for administration, finance, planning and design while construction and O&M are the responsibility of the field organization. BWDB has about 16,300 staff, of whom about 1,500 are Class I managers, engineers, and administrators, and about 14,800 are Class II, III and IV middle and lower level technical and support staff. About one third of BWDB employees are assigned to O&M. However, these staff have also been responsible for construction and rehabilitation of small projects. 1.21 Project Performance Audit Reports (PPAR) prepared for five completed IDA-financed BWDB projectsl indicate that three have been successful, one project (the Barisal Irrigation Project) has not reached its full potential, and one (Drainage and Flood Control I) is questionable. For the Drainage Project, the PPAR indicated that the assumption that incremental dry season production would not have taken place in the absence of the flood control embankment "has not yet been substantiated with appropriate impact studies." However, the PPAR also noted that the largest of the project's investments included significant non-quantifiable benefits of protecting population from periodic flooding. (It should be noted that the benefits of the proposed project, providing protection from saline high tide inundation and reduction in damage from cyclones, are different from the more typical inland flood control projects.) All the completed projects experienced 1. (a) Chandpur Irrigation Project, Cr. 340-BD, PPAR Report No. 3436, dated April 30, 1981. (b) Karnafuli Irrigation Project, Cr. 605-BD, and Barisal Irrigation Project, Cr. 542-BD, PPAR Report No. 6521, dated November 21, 1986. (c) Muhuri Irrigation Project, Cr. 725-BD, PPAR Report No. 8654, dated May 16, 1990. (d) Drainage and Flood Control Project, Cr. 864-BD, PPAR Report No. 8805, dated June 29, 1990.
 serious construction delays. On average, it took about eight years to complete the schemes instead of five years as originally planned. Projects currently under construction and those more recently completed experienced similar delays, most of which occur at the pre-construction stage. There have been significant delays due to time consuming administrative procedures for appointing consultants to prepare feasibility studies and designs. Procedures for acquiring land for construction have been long and complicated and actual acquisition of land often has been delayed because of shortage of local funds. Delays have occurred during the construction stage due to procurement problems, insufficient budget allocations, or delays in release of funds. Poor quality of construction due to inadequate supervision of works by BWDB staff and use of inexperienced local contractors was a major problem in the past. In recent years, BWDB has employed local consultants on several projects to monitor construction works and help maintain quality standards. Quality of works has improved but there is still room for significant further improvement. There has also been improvement in the funding allocations for the IDA-assisted BWDB projects, which have benefitted from dialogue in connection with the Public Resource Management Adjustment Credit (Cr. 2361- BD). 1.22 Potential benefits of past investments in BWDB's projects have not been fully realized due to weaknesses in O&M resulting in deterioration of the systems. The underlying reasons for these weaknesses include: (a) inadequate budget allocations; (b) inefficient use of available funds; (c) deficiencies in BWDB's organizational arrangements, procedures and staff capabilities for O&M; and (d) insufficient farmer participation. Actions to resolve these issues have been agreed under the BWDB Systems Rehabilitation Project (SRP) (Cr. 2099-BD). Of particular importance are agreements for increasing budgetary allocations for O&M, improvements in BWDB's organization for O&M, training programs for BWDB staff and beneficiaries, and measures to increase beneficiary participation in financing irrigation O&M activities. While there have been some notable improvements (expenditures on maintenance doubled from FY89 to FY94), progress on institutional issues has been less than expected. However, recent steps, such as the approval in August 1994 of Guidelines for Peoples' Participation in Water Development Projects, the assignment of staff to implement these Guidelines, and the development of a training program for such staff, appear to indicate renewed commitment to addressing the key issues in this field. 1.23 Since mid-1994 substantial progress has been made on long-standing institutional issues affecting BWDB. Permanent members have been appointed to BWDB's Board (previously staffed largely through "acting" assignments) and the Board's original mandate and authority as an autonomous body has been restored. Acting upon this renewed authority, the Board filled all vacant Chief Engineer positions and delegated increased authority to lower levels of BWDB staff to permit project managers to expedite project procurement and expenditure decisions. A new accounting system, designed to make BWDB's financial transactions more transparent, has now been introduced. (The new accounting system had been designed in 1990 by consultants financed by the Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA) as part of co-financing the Second Small-Scale Flood Control, Drainage and Irrigation Project (Cr. 1870- BD). However, implementation of the new system had been resisted until mid-
 - 9 - 1994). As noted above, Guidelines for Peoples' Participation have been approved, and are being implemented. Finally, BWDB established five task forces on institutional reform, whose recommendations provided the basis for reaching agreement with IDA in September 1994 on a short-term BWDB reform program. This program concentrated on what could be accomplished over the following year, without altering the current allocation of responsibilities between BWDB and other institutions. The reform program included measures affecting all aspects of BWDB activities, including implementation, O&M, accounting, planning, and administration. Key measures, beyond those indicated above, include a phased program to separate staff and responsibilities for O&M and construction in order to focus a portion of the staff on O&M, reforms in personnel planning, evaluation, and promotion policies, and introduction of multi-disciplinary project planning teams. Progress to-date in implementing the reform program is on schedule. 1.24 The reform program concentrates mainly on BWDB and leaves issues involving other institutions in the water sector for further analysis. However, the program includes agreement to undertake studies on such issues, including appropriate institutional arrangements for sector analysis, project evaluation and planning, and mechanisms for decentralization of responsibility and increasing peoples' participation in project formulation and O&M. The FAP reports' institutional recommendations include a merger of the temporary organization established for FAP with an existing, but weak, sectoral planning organization. Under the proposed River Bank Protection Project (RBPP), IDA expects to finance technical assistance to improve sectoral planning capacity (see para 1.16) and carry-out the above referred medium-term studies. 1.25 The proposed project design addresses some of the problems described above, inter alia, through requiring the use of experienced, internationally recruited consultants for supervision of works, using prequalified contractors selected through ICB procedures for the major civil works, using "Class A" contractors (or the equivalent) and agreed minimum contract sizes for the minor works, and incorporating community participation and other measures designed to improve maintenance of project works. Forest Deoartment 1.26 Formerly part of the Ministry of Agriculture, the Forest Department (FD) is now under Ministry of Environment and Forests (MOEF) which was established in 1989. MOEF is in the process of being fully established, but is still weak, especially in the areas of monitoring and evaluating the operations of its executing agencies, interagency coordination, and resolution with other ministries of important intersectoral issues, including land allocation, wood prices, and human resource development. 1.27 FD, headed by a Chief Conservator of Forests (CCF), is the primary GOB agency responsible for the day-to-day management of forest resources in the country. At its headquarters, the CCF is assisted by three Deputy Chief Conservators of Forests (DCCF), responsible for development planning, forest extension, and forest management planning, respectively. Each DCCF is supported by an Assistant Chief Conservator of Forests (ACCF). Reporting to the CCF is also a Conservator of Forests (CF), who with the assistance of two
 - 10 - ACCFs, is responsible for general administration and wildlife. Also, the Directors of both FD's Forest Development and Training Center and the Thana Afforestation and Nursery Development Project are directly responsible to the CCF. 1.28 FD's field operations, consisting of six Circles headed by CFs and concerned with territorial forestry, also come under the CCF's direction. The CF of each Circle is in charge of several forest divisions, which are normally within the boundary of an administrative district, and under the charge of a Divisional Forest Officer (DFO). There are 37 forest divisions including one covering the National Botanical Garden. The divisions are divided into several forest ranges which are controlled by Forest Range Officers, who in turn are in charge of several beats, each under a Deputy Ranger or Forester. The field staff is responsible for the establishment and maintenance of plantations, supervision of state forest lands, provision of industrial wood supplies and extension and public relations at the local level. 1.29 FD's total staff is close to 10,000 including about 4,850 professional and technical staff by the end of 1991. In addition, FD employs a labor force of about 500,000 staff-days/year. The FD has long been a traditional administration-based organization with accountability focussing mainly on adherence to budgetary allocations. Because work quality and effectiveness are not systematically measured, the performance of FD's field staff varies widely. The organization was not sufficiently developed along functional lines, with inadequate specialization of staff. Headquarters' capacity for planning, programming, monitoring and evaluating, and environmental management has been weak. Promotion within FD is almost purely based on seniority with very little attention to merit and managerial and technical capacity. Top managers, especially CCFs, are frequently promoted to their post shortly before retirement, reducing their interest in policy and institutional reform. FD has furthermore been slow to introduce people- oriented forestry development, which, in view of the country's extreme population pressure, is crucial for the establishment, protection, and utilization of forests. While a change in attitude towards people's participation is already evident, clear policies, institutional changes and suitable programs are yet to be developed. Some of these issues are being addressed under the Forest Resources Management Project (Cr. 2397-BD, approved June 1992). In particular, the organization of FD has recently been reshaped along functional lines, in accordance with a revised organizational structure agreed under the credit. However, it would take some time for the new organizational arrangements to affect long-established administrative practices. 1.30 Despite the weaknesses noted above, the overall experience with the two prior IDA-assisted forestry projects has been good. The Mangrove Afforestation Project (Cr. 1042-BD, approved in 1980) achieved an 18% economic rate of return and established over 30,000 ha of new mangrove plantations. The Second Forestry Project (Cr. 1634-ED, approved in November 1985) closed in June 1992, one year later than originally scheduled. Provisions for establishment of 40,000 ha of new mangrove plantations, establishment of 23,000 ha of industrial plantations and maintenance of mangrove plantations have shown good progress. Progress was behind expectation, however, on
 - 11 - components for thinning industrial plantations, improving the forestry data base, and improving in-service training of FD personnel. IDA assistance to the forestry sector continues under the Forest Resources Management Project, which became operational in 1992. This project supports a seven-year comprehensive forestry development program. After a considerable delay in procuring technical assistance and contracting for new aerial photographs, the performance of the project at present is generally satisfactory. However, there are still some policy and institutional reform issues concerning which discussions with the Government are continuing. In addition to IDA-financed projects, FD has undertaken a number of ongoing pilot operations in community participation in forestry, including projects on private and public wastelands and the slopes of railway and road rights-of-way. These projects have involved several non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and have been assisted by such external agencies as ADB and WFP. The proposed project takes advantage of some of the community participation models developed in the inland areas, combined with FD experience in saline tolerant mangrove plantation in the coastal areas. II. THE PROJECT A. Proiect Objectives and Concept Obiectives 2.1 The objectives of the proposed project are: (a) cyclone protection, including improving the security of persons living in the protected areas, reducing damage to houses and other buildings and infrastructure and minimizing the loss of crops and livestock; (b) improved agricultural production, through preventing saline inundation during normal weather and improved cropping patterns due to reduced cyclone risks; and (c) introduction of improved technology in the design and construction of protection works, and improved methods of embankment maintenance. Project Concept 2.2 The proposed project was originally intended to finance the Mid- Term Program to strengthen existing coastal embankments, while a second-stage long-term program was being developed for the construction of embankments and associated structures for the protection of newly accreted lands. In response to the April 1991 cyclone, a portion of the originally intended project has been financed separately under the PWP (see para 1.4) to provide for the most urgently needed embankment repair and rehabilitation work. However, the PWP works are still conceptually part of the Mid-Term Program for coastal embankment restoration. The proposed project would finance in addition to the rehabilitation and improvement of 12 sea-facing embankments, ancillary investments for improved O&M, afforestation, and minor polder improvements covering the ten PWP embankments as well as the 12 embankments referred to
 - 12 - above.2 It would also finance small amounts of work required to complete the PWP embankments in one polder where there had been delays due to disputes concerning the alignment and in another where improvements in drainage are required. For reasonable economy in construction, designs for embankments to protect agricultural land allow for moderate overtopping of embankments during severe cyclones, but not to a degree which would lead to breaching of the embankments or to very high flood levels in the polders. Adequate drainage is also to be provided. Afforestation is provided both to help absorb wave energy and tidal surges during cyclones and to reduce embankment maintenance costs. A community participation approach is to be employed for afforestation and routine embankment maintenance. B. Rationale for IDA Involvement 2.3 In light of IDA's past efforts in assisting Bangladesh to develop programs for dealing with the issue of recurrent cyclones, GOB requested IDA to coordinate donor assistance following the April 1991 cyclone. IDA agreed and assembled the financing package for the PWP (para 1.4). The proposed project would extend the PWP program to additional areas, as well as provide investments to complement those financed under the PWP. The project should also enable IDA to maintain the ongoing dialogue with GOB on appropriate disaster control policies and institutional support. Finally, the proposed project would protect past and ongoing IDA investments in the coastal belt, specifically the Coastal Area Rehabilitation Project (Cr. 339-BD) completed in 1980, Flood Rehabilitation Project (Cr. 1587-BD) completed in 1986, which included repair of damages caused by the May 1985 cyclone; Second Flood Rehabilitation (Cr. 1876-BD) completed in 1989, which included repair of damage during the 1987 floods; and the ongoing Second Small Scale Flood Control and Drainage Project (Cr. 1870-BD). A revised Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) is scheduled to be presented at the same time as this operation. The CAS emphasizes, inter alia, the importance of agricultural growth, development of rural infrastructure, and the need to reduce the negative impact of flooding on people's lives and livelihood. C. NGOs would be employed to assist in mobilizing the community, provide training of participants and facilitate community implementation of these project activities. The project design, including embankment parameters, use of afforestation and community participation in maintenance, reflects the results of studies to determine a cost-effective design with reduced maintenance costs.

Proiect Area 2.6 The polders (Annex 2) covered in the project are spread over the coastal belt surrounding the Bay of Bengal, from Teknaf on the southeast tip of Bangladesh to Sharankhola at the southeast border of Bagerhat District. Of the 21 polders covered in the project, 18 are in the southeastern part of the country and 3 are in the southwest. The number of inhabitants in the project area is about 1.2 million or about 200,000 households. About 70% are farmers. The gross area is about 240,000 ha of which about 80% is under cultivation. Agricultural productivity is low due to salinity and threat of cyclones. Industrial activity is concentrated in the Chittagong area (included in the PWP). E. Detailed Features Rehabilitation and ImDrovement Works 2.7 Maior Civil Works (base cost US$35.1 million). The civil works program would include: (a) major resectioning and/or retirement of embankments (including resectioning of about 78 km of embankments and about 73 km of new retired embankments) in areas where protection of embankments at the existing locations is technically or economically not feasible; (b) about 7 km of new or repaired protection works in the form of block revetments to protect embankment slopes against damage due to cyclonic storms; (c) replacement or repair of existing drainage structures (regulators or drainage sluices); and (d) new drainage structures. The above program includes about US$3.4 million of works to complete the PWP embankments. It also includes about US$2 million of works, to be designed during the first year of project implementation, to deal with recent erosion in a 6 km portion of one of the polders (Sandwip). All works under this category would be carried out on contracts awarded following ICB procedures. 2.8 Armored embankments for protection of agricultural land and the population living in the protected area are not economically feasible or justifiable. Therefore, a cost-effective design with lower maintenance cost is adopted in the project. The sea-facing embankments are designed as compacted earthfill dams with a protective layer of a meter of clay cover along the outer slopes and crest, slopes of 1 on 7 on the sea-facing side and 1 on 3 on the country side, a 50 meter to 200 meter wide strip of foreshore afforestation and a crest level established according to the following criteria: for normal monsoons and cyclones of the intensity expected once in five years, no significant overtopping would occur; for more severe cyclonic storms expected once in 20 years, wave overtopping should not result in an average water depth in the polder exceeding 1 meter; and for storms of the intensity expected once in 40 years, crest level should not be lower than the still water level. (For the Chittagong industrial areas financed under the PWP, the design criteria used provide for no significant overtopping, even for storms expected only once in 40 years). With these design criteria and particularly the clay layer, the flatter slopes and the protection afforded by afforestation and forest cover of the slopes, annual erosion of earthfill would be limited to about 900 m3 per km. A very limited quantity of armored
 - 15 - protection is provided in places where retirement is not possible and no foreshore area is available for afforestation. In such areas, revetment blocks of sufficient weight and thickness and placed on geotextile filters are provided. The regulators and surface sluices are designed according to BWDB design criteria. 2.9 Minor Civil Works (base cost US$9.5 million). The civil works program would include: (a) minor embankment repairs mainly on the non-coastal sections including any minor repairs to the sea-facing sections;3 (b) re- excavation of the drainage network within the protected area and the outfall canals; (c) minor repairs to existing revetment works; (d) repair or replacement of drainage regulators in areas not included in the program of coastal embankment repairs; (e) new surface sluices to drain isolated drainage congested pockets within the protected area; and (f) surveying and investigations limited to minor civil works. The slopes and crest width of interior and marginal embankments of the minor works program would conform to the Coastal Embankment Project design criteria, prepared by Leedshill-DeLeuw Engineers and approved by BWDB. Crest levels would conform to the design criteria of the major civil works. Works other than re-excavation of drainage canals would be carried out on contracts awarded following NCB procedures. Re-excavation of khals (base cost US$3.1 million) are expected to be carried out under the Food For Work (FFW) program. 2.10 BWDB Engineering and Administration (base cost US$2.7 million). Improved Operation and Maintenance (base cost US$5.4 million) 2.15 The project would support an improved O&M program for the 21 polders included under the project. All polder infrastructure, including the sea-facing and non-coastal reaches of the embankment, drainage regulators, surface sluices and the drainage network would be included in the program. In the past, O&M activities were not clearly defined, allocations under the recurrent budget were inadequate, BWDB field staff were not sufficiently experienced, and the benefiting community was not involved in maintenance activities. Cuts on the embankment to accommodate houses and cultivation of the slopes with annual crops weakened the embankment. In these conditions, no effective system of O&M could be carried out. Environmental Aspects 2.27 The proposed project has been placed in environmental screening Category B. Most physical works consist of rehabilitation and improvements of existing infrastructure in the polders. The project would improve the environmental conditions by providing additional security against cyclone and monsoon damage, ensuring that salinity intrusion is controlled, increasing forested areas and reducing or eliminating drainage congestion with consequent reductions in health hazards. The rehabilitation program would not have adverse effects on fisheries, since the polders of the Mid-Term Program have no permanent water bodies (beels or haors), and since the embankments do not close up major or medium rivers or shoot channels of these rivers which are the main routes for migration of fish to the spawning grounds in flood plains. Regulator operations on the khals would be designed to facilitate fishing. Shrimp inlets have been included where necessary. Freshwater pond fish cultivation (dominated by carp) would be benefited by protection from cyclone surges and saline intrusion into ponds. The borrow pits inside the embankments could also be used to increase pond fish cultivation. There would be some increase in the use of fertilizer and pesticide in the project area, since the project would enable farmers to switch from local to high yielding varieties. However, over-use of fertilizer and pesticides is not generally a problem in Bangladesh. Farmer training in proper fertilizer and pesticide use is included under the ongoing IDA/ODA financed Agricultural Support Services Project (Cr. 2233-BD). The proposed project provides for the resettlement of
 - 25 - squatters and others who may become landless as a result of land acquisition (see paras 2.12 and 2.19). The technical assistance component includes funds for monitoring the effects of project works during the implementation period and training to increase environmental awareness within BWDB. Financing for mitigating measures required to remedy adverse effects would be available under the rehabilitation and improvement component. Further details on environmental aspects are in Annex 10. The project is expected to lead to increased agricultural production due to three major factors: (a) prevention of salinity intrusions and storm surges during normal monsoons and cyclones; (b) adoption of high yielding varieties (HYVs) because the increased security provided against periodic devastation during severe cyclones would encourage the required investment for HYV production; and (c) improvement of drainage conditions in the polders. These factors would lead to increased agricultural output through higher crop yields per ha, increased cropping intensity, shifting cropping patterns from local to HYVs, and accelerated crop diversification. 4.2 It is anticipated that yield per ha per cropping season would increase by 10-15% for the same crop variety due to protection against intrusion of saline water, improved drainage conditions in the kharif season16, and protection against flooding caused by cyclones and storm surges or heavy rainfall during the monsoon. It is also expected that in the absence of the project, increased salinity due to existing or imminent breaches in the embankments, poor drainage and flooding would, over time, reduce yields to the level observed outside the embankments. All current HYV production would switch to local varieties within two years and the average yield of local varieties of rice would be reduced over a period of five years to about one ton per ha, which is the average yield of T. Aman under saline conditions. 4.3 Cropping intensity in the project area ranges from 108% (Polder 35/1) to 174% (Polder 72), the average being 136%. The national average is about 171%. Saline soil conditions limit crop cultivation during the dry season. Cropping intensity in the "with project" situation is expected to increase by about 20%. The area under kharif crops would increase due to protection from floods as well as improved drainage and the area under rabi crops17 would increase as a result of soil salinity reduction. With the project, the cropping intensity is expected to range from about 130% (Polder 73/1A&B) to 210% (Polder 66/1), the average being 155%. 4.4 Adoption of HYVs of rice is limited in these areas due to high soil and water salinity, as these varieties have little or no tolerance to salinity. With protection against saline water and improvement of drainage conditions, increased cultivation of HYVs of rice is expected to occur. Depending upon the degree of sharecropping in each polder, between 20 and 40% of T. Aman area is expected to shift to HYV in the kharif season. During the rabi season, HYV boro cultivation is expected to increase only in Polder 66/1 where fresh underground water is available for irrigation. Marketing and Prices 4.7 Farmers in the project area sell their surplus crop production largely through the traditional marketing system in which prices are determined by market forces. The system seems to work fairly efficiently. Many farmers sell some portion of the output immediately after harvest to meet their cash requirements, and then buy some of the same products later in the season to meet their consumption needs. The increased crop production is not expected to create any major marketing difficulty despite the record performance in rice production at the national level in recent years. Rice shortages exist in the areas covered by the project. The expected increase in production is not likely to have a substantial impact on the national level. Bangladesh still imports some of the foodgrains required for domestic consumption, especially in years of bad weather. Benefits and Beneficiaries 5.1 The main project benefits would be fewer human lives lost and less property destroyed during cyclones, and prevention of salinity intrusions and storm surges during normal monsoons, leading to increased agricultural production and employment. Complementary works under the project would improve drainage, further increasing agricultural production. Social forestry for cyclone protection and embankment maintenance would have ancillary benefits in poverty alleviation, environmental improvement, and increased output of wood and other forestry products. 5.2 The operation would directly benefit about 1.2 million people living in the project area. This includes about 600,000 people living where the sea-facing embankments would be rehabilitated and another 600,000 people benefitting from improved embankment O&M, afforestation, and minor embankment improvements for polders for which the rehabilitation of the sea-facing embankments was financed under PWP. 20. There would be an exception for two polders as discussed in the footnote to para 2.12.
 - 43 - Protection of Human Lives 5.3 Benefits in human lives saved are impossible to quantify and are not included in the economic analysis. However, it is estimated that about 140,000 people were killed in the project area during the 1991 cyclone. The embankments would help save lives during future cyclones. Although overtopping could still occur after the construction of the new embankments, the flooding of the polders would be slowed and reduced. The massive sudden flooding of 1991, which happened due to breaches in the embankments or missing sections, would not happen in a "with project" situation. Delayed flooding would give more time for the people to escape to safer areas or cyclone shelters. Production Benefits 5.4 Most of the quantifiable benefits would come from increased crop production in normal years. The embankments would protect a gross area of about 191,000 ha (excluding the area protected by sea-facing embankments financed under PWP). The project would directly benefit about 66,500 ha of net cultivable land21 through protection from saline inundation and through improved drainage. This would increase annual crop production at full development from about 157,400 m tons in the "without project" scenario to 245,100 m tons in the "with project" scenario (an increase of about 40W and 56W over the present and "without project" situation, respectively). 5.5 Beyond the benefits afforded during monsoons and normal cyclones, the embankments would provide additional benefits from protecting crops and livestock during major cyclones. It is conservatively estimated that about 50* and 40% of the crops would be saved in the case of cyclonic surges with a return period of 10 and 20 years, respectively. Over 50,000 head of cattle were lost during the 1991 cyclone; many would have been saved had the embankments not breached. Improved embankments and sluices would also preserve shrimp farms, culture fisheries and salt production. Protection of Property and Infrastructure 5.6 The project would protect houses, schools and administrative and commercial buildings. About 864,000 houses were destroyed and another 774,000 were damaged during the 1991 cyclone. Protection would also be provided to public infrastructure such as roads, bridges and culverts. Regulators and other infrastructure in shrimp farms would also be saved, especially from cyclones with a return period of 10 and 20 years. Those variables are: (i) a failure of community participation in embankment maintenance, causing O&M cost to increase above projected levels; (ii) implementation delays (due to institutional weaknesses,
 - 47 - inadequate counterpart funds, and land acquisition problems) leading to escalation in investment costs and deferral of benefits; and (iii) less than expected increases in agricultural production. Adverse changes in the sensitivity variables needed to reduce the project ERR to 12%, are larger than considered likely. 5.16 Effect of insufficient community participation. The potential adverse effects of insufficient community participation would be to lower benefits and to raise both OM and investment costs. If the embankments are not maintained properly and there is intrusion of saline water, then agriculture benefits would fall, the life of the embankments would be shorter and benefits from infrastructure protection would be less. If the life of the embankments is reduced due to inadequate maintenance, major additional expenditure on embankment rehabilitation would be incurred in year 10 and again in year 27 after project completion. Major expenditure on embankment rehabilitation in year 10 and 27 after project completion (a proxy for the cost effects of inadequate maintenance) would reduce the average ERR for the 11 polders from 19.2% to 17.1%. 5.17 Effect of implementation delays or overestimation of production increases: Implementation delays would defer benefits. Overestimation of yields or of the rate of farmer conversion to HYV would also reduce benefits. A reduction in the major benefits has been included in the sensitivity analysis. Switching values have been calculated at a discount rate of 12% for individual benefit items in the NPV/ERR calculations to show the potential effect of the risks for each of the 8 polders having estimated ERR on quantifiable benefits above 12%. The variables that have been tested in the risk and sensitivity analysis include delays in completion of construction and decrease in major quantifiable project benefits (agricultural, afforestation, and non-agricultural benefits). 5.18 Table 5.1 shows that to bring the ERR on quantifiable benefits below 12% would require a combination of a two year delay in project completion and a decrease in project benefits exceeding 30%, or a three year delay in project completion and a decrease in project benefits of about 20%. Other combinations which would reduce the ERR to 12% would include a two year delay in project completion and an increase in O&M costs of over 30%, or a three year delay and an increase in O&M costs of about 15%. Such combinations of unfavorable developments are considered unlikely. Even then, the additional non-quantifyable benefits of saving human lives would still make the project worth doing.

 -62- ANNEX 3 Page 1 of 11 BANGLADESH COASTAL EMBANKMENT REHABILITATION PROJECT Community Participation and Role of NGOs General 1. Objectives. A community participation approach to afforestation and embankment maintenance would be adopted in order to maximize the benefits of the project for local disadvantaged groups and in order to provide long term low cost O&M of coastal flood control and drainage systems. 2. The approach requires the involvement of NGOs who would assist in training and supervising landless people in O&M, construction and afforestation activities. Specifically, the NGOs would (a) facilitate the resettlement of families displaced by project works to the toe of the embankment where they would be responsible for routine maintenance and afforestation of their allotted sections of embankment, (b) involve landless, and particularly female headed households, in routine embankment maintenance for the entire length of the selected coastal embankments, irrespective of whether rehabilitation works have been carried out, (c) carry out protective afforestation of the foreshore, and (d) mobilize local people to take advantage of other employment opportunities arising from the project (construction works, periodic maintenance, forestry nurseries, agricultural and non-farm activities). In addition NGOs would be involved in monitoring the land acquisition process and in ensuring the Project Affected Persons receive fair and timely compensation. This aspect of NGO activities is described in Annex 9 - Resettlement. 3. NGO Capabilities and Experience. There are over 12,000 NGOs operating in Bangladesh of which some 150 have been identified by the IDA as having development programs for the poor. Their size, capacity and areas of expertise diverge greatly. Many NGOs are members of the umbrella organization, the Association of Development Agencies in Bangladesh (ADAB), which is mandated to improve NGO coordination. ADAB also provides secretariats for fora or sub-groups of NGOs working in specific fields. One such group is the Forum on Forestry and Environment (the forum), which has some 95 members working in the area of community or social forestry. 4. The experience of community forestry has been mainly limited to arrangements on government-owned lands with bodies such as the railways and roads authorities and the BWDB for inland embankments. These lands are leased for short periods to the NGOs, who organize and pay groups to plant trees and receive a share of the produce upon harvesting. A caretaker from the group is paid for by the NGO. The trees are often slow yielding timber species and the land remains the property of the government agency, which generally also receives part of the harvested produce. An exception to this model occurs in the coastal areas where small groups are involved in planting of palms on land around cyclone shelter sites, often donated by the community. There has been no experience to date of the private lease-type arrangements proposed for this project.
 -63- ANNEX 3 Page 2 of 11 5. The NGOs with the most experience in the forestry sector include Proshika (which has worked with winrock International in developing community forestry training modules), Dinajpur and Rangpur Development Scheme (who have a well established and successful social forestry programme in north-western Bangladesh), and BRAC (who have experience in the planting of mulberry trees for sericulture on road and river embankments). In addition, POUSH, CARITAS, MCC (Mennonite Central Committee), CARE and CONCERN have been involved in social forestry along roads and railways lines. 6. At least 40 NGOs are working in the 21 polders covered by this project. They are largely involved in emergency relief, building and maintenance of cyclone protection shelters and land reform. There is a growing experience through programs such as the SRP, and through NGOs' own Land Reform Programs, in working with landless women to form Earthworks Maintenance Groups (EMGs) to carry out routine embankment maintenance for BWDB, and in forming Landless Contracting Societies (LCSs) for road building and maintenance. Many NGOs are also involved in social forestry programs, although these do not appear to involve afforestation of coastal embankments. One NGO (Oiskar International) is believed to be active in community planting of mangroves. 7. Interest of NGOs. Based on discussions between the mission, ADAB and individual NGOs at the national and the local level, there appears to be general support for the approach of the project. In particular many NGOs welcomed the opportunity to transform a major infrastructure project into an opportunity to use a scarce land resource for resettlement of vulnerable landless groups and to treat embankments as income earning assets. All of the NGOs consulted expressed an interest in participating in activities ranging from project design to implementation and monitoring. NGOs wish to be considered as partners, rather than simply contractors, in the project, actively involved from the outset of project implementation in discussions on the preparation of proforma contracts and consideration of proposals for implementation of the project. NGOs stressed that they would prefer to work in areas where they are already established, which highlights the need to identify locally active NGOs to be included on the shortlist of NGOs to be invited to provide services. Activities for Community Participation 8. Areas in which community participation would occur are: (a) Routine embankment maintenance; (b) Foreshore afforestation; (c) Embankment afforestation; and (d) Periodic embankment maintenance. 9. Routine Earthwork Maintenance would be carried out on the total length of embankments rehabilitated and improved under CERP and PWP and limited sections of non-rehabilitated embankments unimpeded by human settlements and plantations (see para 13 (b)). Routine O&M and planting and management of trees on the rehabilitated embankments would be carried out on about 530 km of embankment by squatter and other selected landless households, with priority given to those affected by the project. The selected landless families would be resettled at the toe of the embankment and would be
 -64 - ANNEX 3 Page 3 of 11 responsible for the maintenance of a specific strip corresponding to the length of embankment on which they would have the usufructuary rights for the trees. This is expected to be about one hectare (approximately 250m-300m depending on the height and width specifications of the embankment). In portions of Sandwip and Ramgati, due to the high density of squatters on embankments, they would be organized in groups of about 5-10 families, with each group being allotted a 1 ha section of embankment. Families would have a contract with BWDB and receive direct payment for the first 4 years of operation (from the first year of settlement) at a declining rate as the produce of the trees on the embankment increases.1 Failure to meet their O&M and afforestation responsibilities would lead to sanctions, including in the worst cases, eviction and resettlement of new families on the homestead plot. After a period of 4 years the families would continue to carry out routine O&M but would no longer receive payment (except that if the embankment trees are destroyed in a future cyclone, payment would resume until sufficient subsistence income could be obtained from the trees.) It has been calculated that about 1,800 families, plus about 30 groups of 5-10 families each in Sandwip and Ramgati, would be resettled in this way. 10. Foreshore Afforestation. Afforestation would be carried out on some 4,700 ha of the foreshore by groups of local people trained and supervised by NGOs. Mangroves would be planted on low lying foreshore areas, while other species (see Annex 4) have been identified for higher foreshore areas. Foreshore afforestation would be phased and would be carried out from year 1 of the project, before the completion of construction works. Planting would be carried out in the months of June to August, with mangroves also being planted in December to February. It is expected that groups would have an average of about 15 members who would plant some 12 ha (equivalent to an 0.8 km strip of 100 m or a 1.6 km strip of 50 m)2 However different NGOs would be permitted to use larger or smaller group sizes based on their experience and preferences. Replacement of failed seedling would be carried out in the subsequent 2 years.  - 74 - ANNEX 4 Page 1 of 11 BANGLADESH COASTAL EMBANKMENT REHABILITATION PROJECT Forestry Models A. Introduction 1. Afforestation of embankment slopes and a belt on the foreshore would reduce cyclone damage and embankment operation and maintenance (O&M) costs. The coastal embankments are submerged up to a fair depth during normal tides, with greater submersion occurring during spring tides and cyclones. The eroding actions by the sea waves and cyclone surges cause constant scouring of the embankment base and slopes resulting in damage or, at times, breaches in the embankment. However, it has been observed that wherever groves of standing trees exist on the foreshore, such damage is minimal. The trees, acting as a physical barrier, directly intercept the waves and storm surges and reduce their speed and erosive action. A belt of standing trees of appreciable width along the coastline functions as a wall absorbing and dissipating the first onslaught of storm surges and provides protection of the embankment as well as lives and property of the people living in the area. Also, trees of appropriate species planted on the embankment help hold the embankment soil firmly through their root network. Finally, as a last resort, many people in the affected area survived cyclones clinging to the top of appropriate tree species (without thorns and able to bend in the wind). In addition to reducing cyclone damage and embankment O&M costs, the trees would provide direct economic benefits in terms of their produce and would produce environmental benefits. The foreshore afforestation would also accelerate accretion of new land. 2. The proposed area for afforestation consists of embankment slopes and a 50 to 200 meter wide strip of foreshore (depending on land suitability and availability) of the 21 polders included in the project. Total length of embankment available for afforestation is about 575 km, covering an area of about 1900 hectares on the slopes. On the foreshore, a length of about 440 km, covering an area of approximately 4,700 hectares, would be available for afforestation. (Details of length and area by polder for the embankment slope and the foreshore are given in Tables 1 and 2 respectively.) In addition, an area of 30 hectares out of about 35 hectares provided as homestead land for the participants in embankment maintenance would be available for planting trees or growing crops. Foreshore land, according to a BWDB survey (which covered 20 out of the 21 CERP polders), includes 1,090 ha in the inter-tidal zone and almost 11,000 ha of raised foreshore between the high tide mark and embankment alignment. About half of the raised foreshore is privately owned and used for cropping. There are limited areas of trees, homesteads, shrimp pond and salt pans, but most of the remaining raised foreshore is uncultivated. It is assumed that all the inter-tidal zone would be planted to mangrove. The area of raised foreshore available for planting has been assumed to be 80% of publicly owned, non-used land, and 20% of private and cropped land. Therefore it would need to be regularly cut to a height of l.5m, producing a substantial quantity of fuelwood and fodder. Arhar will produce an edible pulse and fuelwood. Depending on the results of experiments, vetiver may replace arhar in some locations. (iii) Model II: Foreshore 10. Raised foreshore areas with clay soils would be planted with species such as raintree, koroi, khoya babla, simul, and kadam, grown in polypots. Sandy soil and sand dune areas would be primarily planted with jhaw, but other species like eucalyptus camaldulensis and khoya babla would be tried in areas where some proportion of clay is observed. The plant spacing would be 2 m x 2 m. The low lying inter-tidal areas (mud flats) would be planted with mangrove species at a spacing of 1.5 m x 1.5 m. The choice of species would depend on the maturity of the formations and physical characteristics of the topsoil. While new formations would be planted with keora, the comparatively harder soils would be planted with baen, kankra, and gewa.
 -78 - ANNEX 4 Page 5 of 11 (iv) Model III: Homestead 11. Settlers would build a house at the edge of the homestead plot furthest from the embankment facing north or east. The rest of the homestead area would be a kitchen garden growing seasonal vegetables and fruits (banana, papaya, mango). Fuelwood trees and betelnut could also be grown around the plot. It is not envisaged that the project would provide any formal assistance in the cultivation of homestead plots, but NGOs may provide advice and other support on an ad hoc basis. D. Nursery Practice and Cost of Establishment 13. The project would aim to support the development of private sector nurseries, both by procuring as many seedlings as possible from existing sources of supply, and by funding the establishment of additional nurseries by NGOs and individuals. A number of nurseries are already established in project polders by the FD, NGOs and private individuals. Channels have also been developed to bring seedlings in for other areas such as Bola island and Barisal. Although it will not be possible to precisely define nursery requirements until detailed site specific planting plans are drawn up and the capacity of local nurseries assessed, for the purposes of overall project planning it has been assumed that 30% of fruit and timber trees and palms will be procured from outside sources together with 10% of hedging plants. It is assumed that all mangrove seedlings will be produced by project nurseries. Only the production of mangrove seedlings, which require specialist techniques, would remain the exclusive preserve of the forestry department. Project nurseries for other seedlings will be established by channelling funds via NGOs who will either establish nurseries themselves or support the establishment of nurseries by individuals or groups. 14. One year old seedlings, especially in the case of fruit trees and mainland timber species, have a higher rate of survival when transplanted. The general nursery technique would be polypot raised seedlings in 25 cm x 15 cm x 0.08 mm size polypots, except coconut, betelnut, and mangroves, that would be bare rooted, and ipil-ipil that would be raised in 15 cm x 10 cm x
 - 80 - ANNEX 4 Page 7 of 11 0.06 mm size polypots. Seedlings of dholkolmi and sada akand may be grown in polypots or the hedge rows may be established by direct planting or cuttings. 15. The area required for nurseries on each polder has been calculated from forecast seedling requirements and the nursery area required by seedlings of different species (allowing for half the nursery area to be taken by paths and storage areas). Allowances have been made for bought in seedlings, and a failure rate (requiring replanting) of 40% for embankment planting and 100t for foreshore planting. Planting is assumed to be spread over one to four years for embankment species (depending on the embankment construction schedule) and five years (including one year of replacement planting) for foreshore seedlings. On this basis the numbers of nurseries required in each polder.has been calculated in Table 5. The maximum size of a nursery is assumed to be lha, and if the required area exceeds this, additional nurseries will be required. A total of 29 non-mangrove nurseries (average size 0.65ha) and 17 mangrove nurseries (average 0.15ha) would be established. In practice NGO supported nurseries may be considerably smaller, but to split a nursery into a number of sub-nurseries would have minimal impact on project cost projections. Although it has been assumed that it will not be possible to ship seedlings between nurseries on different polders, transport within a polder should not be too much of a problem along the newly constructed embankments. 16. Each nursery would have a supervisors and an average of 14 workers and guards for non-mangrove species, and 7 workers/guards for mangrove nurseries. Each nursery would have sheds for workers' accommodation and storage, together with fencing and tools. Non-mangrove nurseries would need a supply of water (surface tank or tubewells), while mangrove nurseries need a small embankment and simple sluice to control the level of tidal water. Estimated annual production from the proposed afforestation component is summarized in Table 7. The major types of output that would come from afforestation are fruits, vegetables, timber, and fuelwood. About 227,600 tons of fruits and vegetables and 224 million cubic feet of timber and fuelwood are expected to be produced over the project life of 30 years. While 93% of the production of fruits and vegetables is expected to come from the embankment slope and the rest from the homesteads, 96% of the timber production is expected to come from the foreshore. 19. Farm budgets for a one-hectare model farm on the embankment slopes, a 15-hectare model farm on the foreshore, and a 200 m2 homestead farm on the country side toe of the embankment are summarized in Tables 8, 9, and 10, respectively. The beneficiaries would begin to realize net positive incomes from the afforestation, if all inputs including family labor were valued at market prices,3 from the first, fourth, and ninth year of afforestation on the homestead land, embankment slope, and foreshore, respectively. In light of the fact that the Government would provide the seedlings and the first three years requirements of fertilizer and pesticides, and that embankment settlers would be using unpaid family labor, these settlers would be receiving net positive cash incomes from the embankment slope and homestead land from year one and the foreshore from year nine (see Tables 5, 6, and 7). About 30% of the trees in the foreshore would be ready for felling in the ninth year from planting. In the case of the homestead plantation, all fruit trees would be producing and 30% of fuelwood trees would be ready for felling in the sixth year. 3. The seedling costs in the financial models are at market prices, which contain an element of subsidy in that Government prices for seedlings do not cover nursery establishment costs. These additional costs of about Tk 7,800 per ha for nursery establishment and personnel plus the costs of FD vehicles and vehicle operating expenditures and NGO services costs have been added back in for the purposes of economic analysis and project cost estimates.
 -82 - ANNEX 4 Page 9 of 11 20. Fruits and timber would be the two major products expected from the afforestation on embankment slopes and foreshore. There would be adequate demand for these products. Fruits are in short supply in the coastal belt as well as in the rest of the country for most of the year. Hence the farmers are not expected to face difficulties in marketing the increased production of fruits. Fuelwood and timber are also in short supply. The timber is used in constructing houses and building fishing boats. There is a large fishing community in the project area. The coastal areas are well connected by rivers and, to some extent, by roads. Surplus output of fruits, timber or fuelwood in a given area would thus be transported to deficit areas without much difficulty.
