 - 102 - ANNEX 5 Page 1 of 10 BANGLADESH COASTAL EMBANKMENT REHABILITATION PROJECT Improved Operation and Maintenance Introduction 1. The project provides for improved operation and maintenance for twenty one polders located mainly in the south eastern part of the country. Improved O&M would cover: operational activities which need to be carried out to ensure the safety of embankments, to check that drainage canals (khals) are effective, and for the safety and proper operation of drainage structures; and maintenance activities on: (a) about 505 Km of sea facing embankments, and about 260 Km of interior and marginal embankments on the non-coastal side (Table 1); (b) all drainage regulators and surface sluices; (c) the drainage network within the protected area and the outfall canals; and (d) the afforested sections of the embankment slopes. These polders provide protection to agricultural land with the exception of Polder 62, Patenga which protects major public and private properties including the airport, naval academy and export processing zone. The implementing agencies, BWDB and Forest Department assisted by consultants, NGOs and the elected members of the Union Parishad, would carry out O&M utilizing the community particularly landless persons, squatters on embankment, and destitute women. Present Condition Organization and Management. 2. The BWDB Headquarter's Technical Unit under the overall control of the Member O&M assisted by the Chief Engineer O&M is responsible for rehabilitation and improvement of operational projects and the O&M of these projects. The unit comprises an O&M Directorate and a Rehabilitation Directorate headed by Project Directors (level of Superintendent Engineers). The unit is required to: (a) review and consolidate the annual budget requests prepared by field divisions covering operation, maintenance and rehabilitation and establish priorities under budget constraints; (b) develop long term (five years) rolling budget requirements for O&M covering operational projects and projects expected to be completed during the plan period; (c) guide the field divisions in preparing and updating O&M manuals; (d) participate in maintenance reviews, monitor progress and evaluate performance; (e) assist O&M field staff in solving new and difficult problems pertaining to O&M and rehabilitation; and (f) assist the BWDB Training Directorate in preparing and executing O&M training programs. 3. At the field level, there are on average, three subdivisions within a division and each is supervised by a Sub-divisional Engineer (SDE), supported by three Section Officers (SOs)and a variable number of Works Assistants (WAs). Embankment and Sluice Operators (Khalashis) are located at each polder to carry out the operational activities and to assist in ensuring the security of infrastructure. Job responsibilities of all field staff are specified in the basic O&M manual prepared in 1967.for the Coastal Embankment Project.
 - 103- ANNEX 5 Page 2 of 10 Annual Budciets 4. Budgetary requirements for O&M, which includes: operations, routine and periodic maintenance, maintenance during the implementation period of on-going projects, and flood and cyclone damage repairs are provided for under four categories: the revenue budget, development budget, food for work program (FFW) and the foreign exchange budget. The main sources of funding for operations, routine and periodic maintenance are from the revenue budget and the FFW program. The annual divisional O&M budget is based on the following categories: (a) building repairs and construction; (b) protective works; (c) resectioning works; (d) construction and repair of sluices; (e) establishment; (f) transport and equipment; and (g) supply of fall boards and gates. There is no facility for further breakdown of categories into routine and periodic maintenance or secondary categories to enable monitoring of physical and financial progress and establishment of realistic costs for routine and periodic maintenance. BWDB uses up to 90% of its FFW allocations for maintenance activities comprising: resectioning of embankments; breach filling; and re-excavation of drainage channels. A major part (estimated at about 67*) of the revenue budget was utilized to meet the high establishment costs. It has been established by previous studies and as discussed in the SAR for Systems Rehabilitation Project, Cr. 2099-BD (SRP) that the allocation from the revenue budget for actual O&M costs was about 40% short of the actual requirement with the main shortfall recorded in the maintenance category where in FY89 there was an estimated shortfall of about 75%. Under SRP, the Government agreed to increase allocations for O&M by at least 10* a year in real terms. This agreement has been adhered to. The budget for maintenance items (electricity, fuel and maintenance works) in FY94 was about US$12.6 million equivalent, close to double the US$6.5 million allocation in FY89. Problems and Actions Directed to Imvrove OhM 5. Problems could be categorized under two headings: (1) Budgetary: As earlier stated, activities which broadly fit into O&M are financed from four sources. The four budgets are prepared separately and at present there is no system to extract and develop an overall O&M work program. An overall budget with realistic and identifiable items of work: (a) would prove and justify annual requirements based on need; (b) adjust work programs in a logical manner to match the allocation of scarce funds; and (c) assist in the introduction of an effective monitoring system, identify issues and introduce changes in a timely manner; and (2) Maintenance Activities: The present absence of clear definitions of O&M (particularly maintenance) and its objectives provides a severe restraint on the current annual and long term planning of O&M activities. Planning of annual maintenance and the drawing up of a rolling long term plan require: (a) the work activities such as routine and periodic maintenance, and repairs to damages caused by floods and cyclone storms; (b) updating of the inventory of all BWDB facilities; (c) estimating rehabilitation and improvement requirements to bring projects into a condition that routine and periodic maintenance could commence and ensure the project's sustainability;
 -104 - ANNEX 5 Page 3 of 10 (d) work standards and outputs; (e) community participation in routine and periodic maintenance; (f) an assessment of resources (manpower, materials and equipment); and (g) annual work programs and schedules. 6. Operational activities in polders in the coastal belt and flood control projects in the mainland of the country are well defined and could be carried out satisfactorily if all the infrastructure of the polders are completed to the required design and are in an operational condition. In irrigation projects several issues which are constraints to effective operations have been identified and these are being addressed adequately under the IDA financed Second Small Scale Flood Control, Drainage and Irrigation Project, Cr.1870-BD (SSFCDI) and the SRP. Maintenance activities are effected adversely due to several issues which need to be addressed before an effective and sustainable system could be introduced. The issues include: (a) squatters on the embankments and cuts in the embankment slopes to accommodate their homesteads; (b) cultivation of perennial cash crops on embankment slopes; (c) unauthorized planting of trees on the embankment slopes; (d) deep runnels on embankment slopes; (e) earth slips at structures; (f) breaches caused by floods and cyclonic storms, being left in a state of disrepair to face the monsoons; (g) repairs of collapsed protection works not being done in a timely manner; (h) settlement of the embankments due to poor compaction and slopes not done to the designed profile; (i) flap gates at structures in a state of disrepair or in most cases missing; (j) protection works, structural aprons and wing walls of structures, damaged due to erosion; (k) silting up of drainage network particularly in outfall canals affected by tidal conditions. 7. In order to establish a rationale and sustainable plan for O&M and particularly for maintenance, the issues listed above are being addressed under several donor assisted on-going projects such as the IDA financed SRP (Cr.2099-BD) and the SSFCDI Project (Cr.1870-BD); the Dutch financed Land Reclamation Project (LRP), Delta Development Project (DDP), and the Early Implementation Project (EIP); the ADB financed Ganges-Kobadak Rehabilitation Project (GKRP); and the IDA and CIDA financed Operation and Maintenance Cost Cell (O&MCC) under the SSFCDI Project. The Headquarters O&M Technical unit with the separation of rehabilitation and O&M functions and training directed to O&M activities has already been established. The unit is presently addressing aspects of routine and periodic maintenance including costs and the O&MCC is as a first step establishing standards and creating a computer based program for a country wide schedule of rates for construction works. The CKRP Project would establish a system to provide for floods and cyclone repairs in the O&M program. Under the SRP, models are being experimented on for determining the effectiveness of carrying out periodic and routine maintenance by groups of landless persons and destitute women. The CERP Project would address the issue of squatters and cultivation of embankment slopes and direct its effort to involve the community in carrying out all routine maintenance and a major part of periodic maintenance.
 - 105 - ANNEX 5 Page 4 of 10 ODeration and Maintenance Activities 8. Operation. Activities to be executed continuously include: (a) patrolling of the embankment to detect weak sections, slips, signs of squatter settlements, cultivation of perennial cash crops, cuts in the embankment to accommodate homesteads, embankment subsidence and erosion and/or settlement of protection works; (b) regular checks of structures to detect slips at abutments, erosion of aprons, protection works and wing walls, and periodic damage to flap gates and fall boards; (c) regulation of gates if applicable (d) supervision of routine maintenance work. In addition at the beginning of the monsoon, a condition survey (if needed an engineering survey) of the embankment would be needed for estimating the periodic, cyclonic and flood damage repairs to be carried out during the dry season. During the monsoon operational activities would be stepped up to ensure timely action to prevent damage. At the end of the monsoon, operational activities would include: the condition survey of the embankment, and structures and an engineering survey of the drainage network. These surveys would be required to prepare details for carrying out periodic maintenance. 9. Routine or Preventive Maintenance. Activities to be executed continuously include: (a) filling of runnels in embankment slopes and road; (b) filling of minor slips in embankment slopes and abutments and wing walls of structures; (c) repairing of rat holes; (d) preventive measures to stop leaks and piping through the embankment; (e) maintaining recently planted approved type of trees and replacement of trees, turf or grass bush; (f) arresting settlement/erosion in aprons and protection works at structures; (g) arresting collapse of protection works provided for prevention of river bank erosion and wave action on embankment slopes; (h) clearing of debris and water hyacinth in structure intake and outfall canals; (i) greasing of lifting mechanism of regulators and surface sluices; (j) preventing cattle damage by erecting and maintaining fences; (k) maintaining reservations along embankments; (1) preventing new settlements on the embankment and reservations or making of cuts in embankment slopes to accommodate homesteads; and (m) clearing of debris and man-made obstacles, such as fish fences, in the drainage canals. 10. Periodic Maintenance. Activities to be executed during the dry season include: (a) maintaining the design profile of the embankment and drainage canals; (b) repair of breaches and major slips caused by normal annual monsoon and cyclonic storms; (c) repair of protection works provided for arresting river bank erosion and damage due to wave action and providing preventive works to minimize such damage; (d) permanent repairs to arrest piping through the embankment; (e) permanent repairs to arrest damage to aprons, wing walls and revetments at structures; (f) repairs or replacement of flap gates and lifting mechanism of vertical lifting gates and replacement of gate and sill rubber seals; (g) repairs or replacement of trashracks of structures; (h) repairs to eroded concrete at structures; and (i) desilting of drainage canals (frequency to be decided after a study of silting condition). Earthworks would include compaction. Frequency of these activities would depend on hydrological, and tidal conditions of the polder, and the soils used in earthfill of embankments. Generally with effective routine maintenance the frequency would be once every two years.
 -106 - ANNEX 5 Page 5 of 10 11. Repairs to damages caused by floods and cyclonic storms. These repairs are assessed after each storm and are financed under the development budget which is funded by GOB and donor assisted emergency programs. (The IDA, EU, Japan and Saudi funded PWP, and the several IDA and ADB assisted Flood Rehabilitation Projects are a few examples of such works). Repairs include: (a) filling of major breaches including retirements; (b) major repairs to protection works or provision of new works; (c) major resectioning of embankments; (d) repair or replacement of structures; and (e) replacement of trees on embankment slopes. 12. Afforestation. With the exception of the recent introduction of afforestation of embankment slopes on a very limited scale, afforestation has not been introduced as a protection measure. Foreshore afforestation development has not been systematically introduced to be effective as a protection measure to embankments. It has now been established that embankment and foreshore afforestation are the most economical and effective type of protection work to ensure the security of the embankment during cyclonic storms. Maintenance activities include: (a) upkeep of paths to facilitate inspection of trees; (b) clearing around trees; (c) application of fertilizers; (d) harvesting of produce from fruit trees; (e) controlled harvesting of fuel woods and leaves; and (f) replanting according to set guidelines and replacement of diseased or dead trees. Proposals for Improving Operation and Maintenance 13. The sustainability of a rehabilitated and improved polder would depend primarily on effective routine and periodic maintenance. It could only be ensured if the community which is safeguarded by the infrastructure participates fully in these maintenance activities. The chairman and members of the Union Parishad together with NGOs located in the area need to act as facilitators to organize those participating in maintenance, particularly routine maintenance, and help BWDB supervise the adequacy of their work. The Project, while ensuring that technical standards are not sacrificed, provides for a package of incentives to achieve the objective of maximum community participation. 14 BWDB and the Forest Department would be the implementing agencies for the embankment O&M and afforestation and the foreshore afforestation components respectively. All operational activities would be carried out by the staff of BWDB. Routine maintenance of the rehabilitated embankments including the plantations on embankment slopes would be handled by individual families who would be granted contractual rights to the produce of trees in return for their maintenance activities. Until such time as sufficient income is obtained from the produce of the trees, these families would be paid an allowance sufficient to sustain them (para 16 below and Annex 4). The planting of foreshore afforestation would be carried out by community groups and would be financed under the project. Maintenance, harvesting, and replacement planting of harvested trees on public foreshore land would be carried out by community groups, who would receive 75% of the produce. Maintenance, harvesting, and replacement planting of foreshore afforestation on private land would be carried out by the landowners on terms and conditions described in Annex 4. Routine and periodic maintenance of embankments not rehabilitated under the project, including the sections with existing heavy plantations, and the periodic maintenance of embankment sections rehabilitated
 -107 - ANNEX 5 Page 6 of 10 under the project would be carried out either by community groups or, in the absence of such viable groups, by contracts awarded following LCB procedures. Funds for carrying out repairs to damages caused by floods and cyclonic storms during the implementation period are provided for by the project. The provision is adequate to cover storms which occur on average once every 5 years. Damage repairs would be contracted out to local contractors under awards made following LCB procedures. 15. The consultant responsible for implementation support would provide advice and guidance to the implementing agencies in all technical and social aspects of the improved O&M program. In particular, the consultant would establish standards for all O&M activities, carry out work studies on routine and periodic maintenance and khal re-excavation, update project rates and work tasks, and monitor progress and evaluate the impact of the program. During the project perod the consultant would at regular intervals update work tasks, rates and costs. The project cost estimates include funds for seven categories of improved O&M expenditures. These include: (i) operational activities; (ii) routine maintenance of rehabilitated embankments inclusive of maintenance of trees on embankment for a specified period which would be from the end of contractual commitment of the rehabilitation work until the produce of trees on the embankment would provide adequate income; (iii) routine and periodic maintenance of the embankments not rehabilitated and periodic maintenance of the embankments rehabilitated under the project; (iv) routine and periodic maintenance of the drainage network; (v) routine and periodic maintenance of protection works; (vi) routine and periodic maintenance of structures; and (vii) damage repairs to earthworks, protection works and structures, caused by floods and cyclonic storms. IDA financing of operation/maintenance and flood and cyclone damage repairs would be at a declining scale (85% of O&M expenditures through FY99, 65% in FYOO and FY01 and 45% in FY02. Organizational and financing aspects for the O&M activities are given below. 16. Operation. BWDB's existing field divisions and sub-divisions are adequately staffed to carry out effectively all operational activities. However, the field staff lack a proper understanding of these activities and their importance for proper maintenance. Training provided under the project would improve the situation. The project would include the required costs for activities to ensure effective operation of the polders and the work would be executed by the existing field staff of BWDB. Operational costs are estimated on the basis of utilizing one patrol laborer (khalashi) for 6 Km of embankment and one gate khalashi for three structures. Provision is also made for engineering surveys to be carried out annually and an overhead cost of 10% for services rendered by the SO and the SDE. No separate provision is made for patrolling drainage canals as the gate khalashi can perform this task. It is estimated that about Tk 5,000 would be required for 1 Km; 17. Routine or Preventive Maintenance. The responsibility for maintenance would be on the community. BWDB would provide the technical advice and NGOs would be responsible for supervision. BWDB, to ensure that standards are met, would regularly check the work and advise NGOs on measures needed to correct any substandard work (see para 22 below). Squatters and those made landless by land acquisition under the project (and other landless families to the extent of available area) would be settled at the toe of the embankment on the country side and would be given contracts allowing them to
 - 108 - ANNEX 5 Page 7 of 10 reside on this allotment and obtain the produce of the trees on a given section of the embankment. It is estimated that an embankment section of 250 meters (four families per Km) would produce adequate benefits to maintain a family (Annex 4). In return, the family would provide routine maintenance of their section of the embankment and the maintenance of trees in this reach. They would be paid for their embankment maintenance activities by BWDB until the trees had grown sufficiently to provide an adequate income. If hired labor is employed, the cost of routine maintenance to ensure that the designed profile and crest level are maintained throughout the year, and in addition reduce periodic maintenance costs, is estimated at Tk 18,000 per Km or about Tk 4,500 per ha of embankment for the life of the embankment. In addition to plant and maintain trees on the embankment using hired labor would cost about Tk 2,000 per ha on average for the first three years after embankment completion. The arrangements under the proposed project would involve somewhat higher costs during the initial years to sustain families until the trees had reached sufficient maturity but would eliminate the need to pay for routine embankment maintenance thereafter. To sustain families during the period of maturity of trees, each family would receive Tk 9,000 in YR1, Tk 8,000 in YR2, Tk 7,000 in YR3, Tk 6,500 in YR4. The produce of the trees and the homestead plots should be sufficient to provide subsistence from YR5. However, as a contingency to deal with possible delays, cost estimates provide funds in YR5 to cover half the families receiving Tk 4,500 each. The NGOs would monitor the actual earnings from embankment afforestation and homestead cultivation. In case of major disruptions in a polder from the assumed afforestation program, such as might occur due to significant storms or a disease outbreak, the NGOs would recommend appropriate modifications to the declining payment scale. Participating families would also be provided seedlings and technical advice in planting approved species on the embankment and would be reimbursed for their expenditure for fertilizer and pesticides for the first three years. Provision would be made to remove families who do not adequately perform their duties. Modified arrangements would apply in Sandwip (Polder 72) and Ramgati (Polder 59/2) due to the high intensity of squatter settlement. Groups would be organized to take responsibility for embankment afforestation and maintenance, with each family responsible for the maintenance and receiving the benefit of the produce of the trees for a much smaller section of the embankment than in the standard model (perhaps 1/4 to 1/8 ha). This would not be expected to provide subsistence income but (together with the produce from the homestead plot) would supplement whatever sources of income had been maintaining the families up until now. 18. Periodic Maintenance. BWDB, assisted by consultants, would estimate at the end of the monsoon season the requirements for the periodic maintenance of the embankment, drainage regulators and sluices, protection works, and the drainage network. Work plans and procurement methods would be agreed upon and implementation would commence at the start of the dry season and completed before the onset of the monsoons. Efforts would be made to allocate earthwork's contracts to landless groups and destitute women groups. In areas where such groups could not be organized, the work would be on contracts awarded following LCB procedures. The role of NGOs is described in para 22. Earthwork costs have been estimated based on about 800 cubic meters of earthwork performed by labor intensive groups (Tk 30,000 per Km for embankments, Tk 17,000 per Km for khals), protection works repairs based on about 60 cubic meter per Km (Tk 60,000 per Km) and structure repairs at a lump sum of Tk 10,000 per structure. It is estimated that about 90 groups each
 -109- ANNEX 5 Page 8 of 10 with 25 persons would be required to carry out periodic maintenance (29 groups for areas where no rehabilitation and improvement works have been carried out and about 60 for areas where rehabilitation and improvement has taken place). 19. Flood or Cyclone Damacce Repairs. Provision is made in the project for flood and cyclone damage repairs on an annual basis. Costs estimated for a disaster occurrence once every 5 years are calculated on a damage section of about 3 Km (a realistic assumption as the effects of such storms would be limited to about a reach of 3 Km). For storms occurring once every 20 and 40 years, special arrangements would be needed to fund damage repairs. It is expected that if such storms occur after full maturity of the afforested area, damages would be drastically reduced and GOB with its own resources would be able to finance the works. Sections that would be affected by such cyclones are estimated on the basis historical records and not on the full length of the sea-facing embankments. The annual lump sums provided in the cost estimates for damage repairs to the sections are estimated on the basis of rates varying from a maximum of Tk 1,000,000/Km for earthwork, Tk 560,000/Km for protection works and Tk 25,000/No for structures respectively in the first year after completion of rehabilitation work to a minimum of Tk 60,000/Km, Tk 460,000/Km and Tk 10,000/No in the fourth year after completion. The reduced cost is due to the protection afforded by afforestation. Community Participation 20. The concept of community participation in O&M is predicated on past experience which has shown that the maintenance of embankment, particularly routine activities has been minimal if not non-existent. BWDB's record in embankment maintenance is bleak and suggests that this has never been a priority for the Board. Consequently, it is hypothesized that local communities who stand to gain most from well maintained embankments, can be co-opted to undertake routine maintenance on sections of the embankment abutting or lying in close proximity to their lands. The most affected in the local community are the squatter population living on the embankment, the landless (people who have lost their land through erosion during cyclonic storms and river bank erosion and people whose lands are being acquired), and destitute women. These people would benefit most from a scheme which would ensure a subsistence living initially and in due course an adequate income to maintain themselves and their families. The scheme would also open the possibility of income generating opportunities. The project also includes an afforestation program which would be an integral part of the embankment, being the primary source of protection against damage by cyclonic storms. It would be difficult for the Forest Department to manage and maintain a tree planting program on a departmental basis. This points to the desirability of community participation in the afforestation component. 21. Role of Locally Elected Officials and NGOs. It is proposed to establish locally constituted committees at each Union in the project area to coordinate project activities in the Union. Such committees would be headed by the Union Parishad Chairman, and would include the BWDB Subdivisional Engineer, a Forest Department Range Officer, and representatives of the participating NGO and DAE. This committee, particularly the Chairman of the Union Parishad and the NGO, would be responsible, inter alia, for motivation and organizing the individuals and their families to undertake routine maintenance. The committee would also assist in controlling future squatter
 - 110- ANNEX 5 Page 9 of 10 settlements on the embankment. See Annex 3 for details on the role of locally elected officials and NGOs. 22. The main responsibility of the NGOs for embankment maintenance would be to organize the resettled families to carry out effectively the routine maintenance of the embankments rehabilitated under the project. Responsibilities would include: (a) assistance to the implementation agencies and consultants in the resettlement of families; (b) finalizing agreements between BWDB and the families; (c) direction and supervision of routine maintenance activities; (d) certification of interim payments (probably monthly), joint inspections with BWDB to check on the quality of work; and (e) assist in disbursing monies to families. To perform their duties effectively, particularly in the technical aspects, NGOs would receive training in routine maintenance activities. (NGO responsibilities for afforestation are detailed an Annex 3). For periodic maintenance, since supervision and payments require special skills which cannot be achieved without going through a detailed engineering course (e.g topographical surveys, setting out etc.), NGOs would assist in the formation of groups including the appointment of the group leader and in administration and financial aspects of contract management such as maintaining accounting documents and disbursement of monies to the group members. BWDB would be responsible for awarding contracts, setting out and supervision, measurements and payments to the group leader who would be the signatory in the contract document. 23. Role of the ImDlementation Support Consultant. The scope of the consultant services on social development activities which is directed mainly on assistance to form effective community participation is described in detail in Annex 6. Imlementation Schedule 24. Under project financing, operational activities and maintenance on embankment sections completed under the PWP would commence in the first year of the project (FY96), maintenance activities on the embankments rehabilitated under the project would commence after the contractual commitments of the civil work's contracts are fulfilled, generally in project year 3 or 4 (FY98 or FY99). Community participation in maintenance activities is described in detail in Annex 3. Estimated Cost 25. The total cost over a period of seven years is estimated at Tk 262.6 million (US$6.0 million) inclusive of price contingencies (no allowance is made for physical contingencies) or about Tk 340,000 per Km for a length of about 770 Km falling under the maintenance program of the project for the project period of seven years. The annual cost of O&M based on YR4 of the post project period would be about Tk 46 million (US$1.1 million) or Tk 59,000 per Km (US$1,500 per Km) excluding the cost of routine maintenance which would be carried out by families. The O&M requirements for the polders during project implementation (yearwise) and after the project period are given in Table 3 of this annex. (The above cost estimates exclude a total during the project period of about $0.3 million equivalent for reimbursing embankment settlers for fertilizer and pesticides for the first three years of

The fertilizer and pesticides would be financed under the forestry component of the project.) 26. Of the total project cost for O&M, GOB would finance about US$2.1 million and IDA about US$3.9 million. The cost of routine maintenance of most of the rehabilitated embankments would continue to be financed by IDA and GOB during the project period as it is estimated that families responsible for this maintenance activity would continue to be dependent on the subsistence allowance until the fifth year of planting (with a contingency provision for some families still needing continued subsistence payments in the fifth year). However, families on PWP financed embankments would be expected to become independent of such subsistence payments during the project period, while families to be settled on the embankments financed under the minor works program would require continued subsistence payments for a few years after the project period. During the first and second post project year, the estimated annual cost of O&M to be borne by GOB would be about Tk 53 million and Tk 49 million respectively in (FY95 prices) and when remaining families take over the full responsibility (physical and financial) in the third post-project year, the cost would reduce to Tk 46 million.  - 119 - ANNEX 6 Page 1 of 26 BANGLADESH COASTAL EMBANKMENT REHABILITATION PROJECT Technical Assistance for Project Implementation and Evaluation 1. This Annex provides draft Terms of Reference for consultant's services to assist the implementing agencies in: (a) construction planning and supervision of civil works in the rehabilitation and improvement component; (b) the afforestation program; (c) the operation and maintenance of infrastructure of the polders; (d) the maintenance of the foreshore afforestation development; (e) organizing with the assistance of the NGOs for communities to effectively carry out routine maintenance and afforestation of the embankment and foreshore afforestation; and (f) monitoring and impact assessment. Background 2. The severe cyclone, which hit the south eastern part of the country on April 29, 1991 caused extensive damages to the coastal embankment and left large areas virtually unprotected against tidal flooding and cyclone surges. The Government of Bangladesh (GOB) through a Priority Works Program (PWP) commencing in FY93 is near to completion of a program of reconstruction and improvement works of the sea facing embankments in ten polders included in the Mid-Term Plan which were the worst affected by the cyclone. Work includes about 190 km of embankment resectioning, 60 km of retired embankments (new), allied protection works and repair or replacement of drainage structures. Under the on-going technical assistance financed by the European Community (EC) consultants provide the project support which includes: (a) the preparation of engineering documentation; (b) assistance in the evaluation of bids following ICB procedures; (c) contract management and supervision of all contracts awarded following ICB procedures; (d) training of staff in preparation of tender documents, supervision organization, quality control, site administration, and contractual and legal aspects of contract management; and (e) monitoring and evaluation of the social impacts, and planning social development programs including a system for the future Operation and Maintenance (O&M) of the completed polders mainly directed towards the participation of the community. In addition, consultants are responsible for the preparation of engineering documentation inclusive of tender documents for the eleven polders of the Coastal Embankment Rehabilitation Project (CERP) with new major works. The social development team are also assisting in developing programs for community participation in CERP. 3. Project support for CERP, whilst continuing the emphasis on supervision and contract management of major civil works contracts to be awarded following ICB procedures, would include: (a) review, updating and, as appropriate, revision of detailed engineering documentation of minor civil works prepared by Bangladesh Water Development Board (BWDB) and the Systems
 - 120 - ANNEX 6 Page 2 of 26 Rehabilitation Project (SRP); (b) assistance in field supervision and quality control of minor civil works; and (c) assistance to the effective implementation of the afforestation component and the improved O&M component. The program of civil works would cover: (i) major reconstruction for about 78 km of embankment resectioning, 73 km of new embankments, protection works and allied drainage structures of the twelve polders (including work remaining in one PWP polder); and (ii) in seventeen polders, minor works comprising about 130 km of embankment resectioning, 4 km of new interior embankments, repairs/replacement of about 145 allied drainage structures, and about 390 km re-excavation of drainage canals (khals). The programs of afforestation and improved O&M would be undertaken in twenty-one polders. Scope of Consultant Services 4. The consultant's services would cover the following: (a) contract management and supervision of all major civil works under the direction of the BWDB inclusive of monitoring of progress and quality control; (b) assistance to BWDB in the tendering and award of two ICB contracts (one major works and one minor works) for completion of PWP works and one ICB major works contract of additional works (tentatively estimated to require 6 km of retirement) to cope with recent erosion. Past experience indicates that progressive deterioration of embankments due to poor maintenance aggravated the collapse of embankments during cyclonic and monsoon storms. Although BWDB has adequate staff to carry out operational activities, they are not capable at present of identifying and supervising maintenance activities which are critical to a sustainable system. It is reported that in addition to budgetary constraints, the lack of motivation and training in maintenance activities are the main
 - 126 - ANNEX 6 Page 8 of 26 reasons for the present unsatisfactory situation. The project's main focus would be to introduce a system that would include routine or preventive maintenance carried out throughout the year and periodic maintenance (proposed once every two years) carried out during the dry season. In addition, during the project period, funds are provided for repairs to damages caused by floods and cyclonic storms of a scale expected to occur on average up to once every five years. The Government's contribution to the repair of such damage could be provided when a disaster occurs. It is expected that with afforestation as the main protection measure, once the trees have grown sufficiently, damage due to disasters would be minimized and for normal annual cyclonic and monsoon storms, maintenance costs would be drastically reduced and eliminated if routine maintenance is carried out effectively. Activities for an effective program for improved O&M are described in detail in Annex 5. Consultant's role would be to assist the staff of the implementing agencies, and, with major input from participating NGOs, to motivate and guide the elected members of the Union Parishad and the benefitted community, in carrying out maintenance activities. Afforestation Development is critical to the security of the embankment. It is cost effective and replaces the high cost option of block revetment works which in the past have not been effective. This would provide an opportunity to ascertain the communities interest in the afforestation component within a social forestry concept.  - 152 - ANNEX 8 Page 1 of 3 BANGLADESH COASTAL EMBANKMENT REHABILITATION PROJECT (CERP) Crop Production and Incomes A. General 1. Estimation of the project's expected impact on agricultural production and farm incomes has been based on a detailed analysis of farming practices and agro-ecological conditions in each of the 11 polders with major works financed under the project. Each of the polders has been considered as a sub-project. The analysis, based on a one hectare farm model, has been done separately for each polder because of differences such as management practices, intensity of input use, soil quality, yields and cropping patterns between polders in the area covered by the project. Prevention of salinity intrusions and storm surges and improved drainage conditions in the polders during normal monsoons and cyclones would lead to increased agricultural production. Higher output would come from changes in cropping patterns and intensity and improved crop yields. In projecting the impact of the project on agricultural production, account is taken of the small amount of land lost to production due to project related land acquisition in areas where embankment retirement is necessary. Account is also taken of further retirement of sections of the embankments in Polders 59/2 (Ramgati) and 72 (Sandwip) expected to be required in year 15 due to erosion. B. Cropping Patterns and Intensity 3. The predominant crop in the area covered by the project is the low yielding local variety (Lv) of T. Aman. B. Aus (LV) is the second major crop in the area. B. Aman is also important in some of the polders. A range of other crops such as pulses, oilseeds, millet, cowpea, chilli, sweet potatoes, jute, and vegetables are grown during the rabi (winter) season. Adoption of high yielding varieties (HYVs) of rice is limited in these polders because of high soil and water salinity as these varieties have little or no tolerance to salinity. All current HYV production is expected to switch to local varieties within two years in the absence of the project given the present condition of the embankments. Rehabilitation of the embankments would prevent salinity intrusions and storm surges and thus bring about changes in the cropping pattern. The present and expected cropping patterns in the "with project" and "without project" scenarios are detailed polder by polder in Tables 1-11. With protection against saline water and improvement of drainage conditions, increased cultivation of HYVs of rice is expected to occur. The increased security to be provided by the rehabilitated embankments would encourage the investment in higher input levels required for HYV production. With the project, between 20 and 40% of T. Aman area is expected to shift to HYV in the kharif season 1, depending upon the degree of sharecropping in each polder, since the incentives to sharecroppers to shift to HYV are much diminished. 1. Summer cropping season (May through November).
 - 153 - ANNEX 8 Page 2 of 3 During the rabi season 2, HYV boro cultivation is expected to increase only in Polder 66/1 where fresh underground water is available for irrigation. Cultivation of HYVs of other rabi crops such as water melon and betel leaf would also increase in the "with project" situation, especially in the polders in Cox's Bazar area such as Polder 66/1 and Polder 68. It is also expected that more land would come under diversified crops (pulses, oilseeds, chillies, winter vegetables, and sweet potatoes) in the rabi season due to reduced soil salinity. Changes in the cropping pattern are expected to be realized over a period of seven years. 4. Cropping intensity in the project area under the present conditions ranges from 108% (Polder 35/1) to 174% (Polder 72), the average being 136t. The national average is about 150%. Saline soil conditions limit crop cultivation during the dry season. The project is expected to increase cropping intensity in the area to the national average because of increased area under both kharif and rabi crops. The area under kharif crops would increase due to protection from flooding as well as improved drainage while the area under rabi crops would increase as a result of soil salinity reduction. Cropping intensity is expected to range from about 130% (Polder 73/1A&B) to 210% (Polder 66/1), the average being 155%, in the "with project" scenario. 5. Aside from the yield gains from switching to HYV and increased cropping intensity, yield per season for the same crops would also increase, due to reduction in salinity, improvement in drainage conditions during the kharif season, and protection against flooding caused by heavy rainfall during normal monsoons or cyclone surges. An increase of 10-15% in yield is expected, the level depending on crop varieties and specific conditions in a given polder. In the absence of the project, yields for most crops would remain low or decline to the levels observed outside the embankments. Due to the effects of salinity intrusions through existing breaches in the embankments or areas where breaches are imminent, and poor drainage and flooding, it is anticipated that in the "without project" situation the average yield of local varieties of rice would be reduced over a period of five years to about one ton per hectare, which is the average yield of T. Aman under saline conditions. Anticipated changes in crop yields under "with project" and "without project" compared with the present conditions are also detailed in Tables 1-12. C. Crop Production 6. Expected annual crop production under present, "without project" and "with project" situations are also detailed in Tables 1-11 by polder. Estimated annual incremental crop production is expected to range from about 20% (Polder 70) to 110% (Polder 40/2), the average being about 55%. Annual production, at full development, with the project is expected to increase by about 87,700 metric tons on average over the "without project" situation. This production estimate is based on a net cultivable land of about 49,900 hectares in the polders protected by the 11 embankments included under the major works program and excludes the cultivable land protected under the 2. Winter cropping season (November through May).
 -154- ANNEX 8 Page 3 of 3 Priority Works Project or by the two Km of embankment improvements provided for polder 60.3 The expected increase in production would be higher if not for the constraints that the farmers will still face. These constraints include limited fresh water for irrigation during the dry season, unfavorable tenancy agreements4 that discourage tenant farmers from investing in land improvement and intensive cultivation, existence of absentee/large land owners who do not pay much attention to crop intensification, and poor quality of draught animals and shortage of mechanical cultivators for land preparation. These constraints have been taken into account when projecting the increase in crop production. The target production is expected to be achieved in seven years' time when the projected changes in cropping pattern and intensity will have been realized. D. Farm Incomes 7. The project's effect on annual farm incomes in the area has been analyzed through the use of one hectare farm models prepared for each of the 11 polders. Prices of all inputs and outputs are based on constant 1994 farmgate prices (see Annex 11, Tables 1 and 2). Details on these prices are discussed in Annex 11, para 1 (c). The cash flows are in constant 1991 taka. Farm budgets detailing input use, costs of production, gross value of production, and net income per hectare for each polder are shown in Tables 12- 23. The results show that investment in the project would increase incomes of farm families in the area substantially. The average net increase in income from one hectare farms would range from about 20% (Polder 59/2) to 110l (Polder 35/1). In value terms, the range would be from about Taka 2,100 (Polder 73/lA&B) to Taka 11,300 (Polder 66/1). The average increase in net income from a one hectare farm for all the polders would be about Taka 5,200 or 47%. The increase is expected to be higher in polders in Cox's Bazar district, where intensive cropping is practiced, than in polders in Burguna or Bagerhat districts. The additional farm incomes would also benefit tenants and landless laborers, in addition to benefiting owner-operators. The percentage share of the benefits is not expected to differ substantially from the present arrangements. Everybody would gain in proportion to present income levels. 3. More time is required to test the effectiveness of recently completed anti- erosion works before firm estimates can be justified. 4.  - 179 - ANNEX 9 Page 1 of 6 Land Acquisition and Resettlement Background 1. There are two major categories of Project Affected Persons (PAPs) under the proposed project: (a) Squatters living on existing embankments being repaired under the project; and (b) People affected by land acquisition for project facilities. About 675 ha is to be acquired under the project consisting of (a) about 270 ha of land in areas where embankments have to be retired due to the effects of erosion on existing embankments; (b) about 175 ha for repair of existing embankments, of which about half is for acquisition of land under one existing embankment where the land had previously been made available on a voluntary basis, without transfer of ownership, and the remainder is land required for widening of existing embankments; (c) about 55 ha for new drainage structures; (d) about 35 ha for minor works (excluding khal excavation); (e) about 35 ha for resettlement of embankment squatters and other landless people; and (f) about 105 ha to be leased for three years in strips of 10 meters width on each bank of kahls, as spoil dump areas for khal excavation. 2. Paras. 2.12 and 2.16 of the SAR describes the program under which about 700 families presently squatting on embankment sections to be rehabilitated and about 1300 other landless families would be allocated an area of the embankment of about 1 ha each (smaller areas in sections of two polders) for which they would be responsible for afforestation and routine embankment maintenance. Each of these families would also be allocated a homestead plot of 10 m. by 20 m. at the inland toe of the embankment. They would be paid by BWDB on a declining scale for these services for about four years by which time the value of the produce from their trees and their homestead plots is expected to be sufficient to provide an adequate income. It is expected that most of the squatters required to move to permit rehabilitation of embankments would opt to move immediately to new homes at the back of the homestead plots, which would still allow contractors enough room on the berm for construction activities. Alternatively, they would be given the option of a rental allowance for about one year to cover the costs of temporarily renting a plot or a house during construction. Squatters would be provided a house construction grant sufficient to cover the costs of movement and erection of shiftable materials from the prior house and purchase and erection of non-shiftable materials for the new house. A squatter census report was produced in August 1993 by the consultants employed for the PWP project. The resettlement consultants, assisted by NGOs, would formally register the eligible PAPs, and would include any new squatters up to the date of the new survey.
 - 180 - ANNEX9 Page 2 of 6 3. On about 3.7 km of embankment near Sandwip town and about 4 km near Ramgati a variation of the above arrangements would be made for squatter families with work or family connections requiring them to live near town. A continuous berm would be constructed to accommodate about 1 00 families near Sandwip and 80 families near Ramgati. Groups would be organized to take responsibility for embankment afforestation and maintenance, with each family responsible for the maintenance and receiving the benefit of the produce from a smaller area than in the standard model (perhaps 1/4 to 1/8 ha). This would not be expected to provide a subsistence income but (together with the produce from the homestead plot) would supplement their current sources of income. Impact of Land Acquisition 4. Land acquisition in Bangladesh in the past has caused severe adverse impacts on affected people, for the following reasons: (a) the level of compensation for land has generally been far below the market value of the lost properties; (b) Compensation has frequently been delayed; (c) Because of the small average land holdings in Bangladesh, people are extremely vulnerable to losses of productive land; and (d) Some categories of affected people have not been compensated. 5. In compliance with the principles of the Bank's Operational Directive 4.30, a resettlement action plan (RAP) has been prepared for the project, which addresses the above-mentioned problems. The main challenges of this plan have been to: (a) develop an improved mechanism for valuation of land; (b) develop policies which adequately address the need for restoring income levels of agriculture-based households; (c) identify and define non-property owners in need of assistance; and (d) provide an adequate and fair grievance mechanism. 6. A socio-economic survey has been carried out by consultants (Bangladesh Institute of Development Studies staff members) of the land to be acquired for embankment retirement. This study covered a total of 236 ha of land required as compared to about 270 now estimated to be required for embankment retirement, taking account of changes in alignment due to erosion and the addition of a section of one polder not completed under the PWP program. This survey aimed to: (i) produce a comprehensive listing of all PAPs; (ii) ascertain the socio-economic status of PAPs; (iii) make a complete list of all losses suffered by PAPs;
 - 181 - ANNEX9 Page 3 of 6 (iv) gather data on the prevailing market price of land; (v) elicit PAPs' views on compensation levels and modalities. 7. Data from the complete census of PAPs has been entered into a computer data- base and two listings produced for each of the 10 polders. One of these contains tables showing informnation on each plot, referenced by the plot number from the mouza map. The second contains a data sheet for each individual PAP. Although the information in these print-outs is quite comprehensive, further information would need to be accessed directly from the data-base. For instance, although PAP data sheets show the value of losses of assets, such as houses and trees, information on the type, size and unit value of each house or tree (which is needed to determine the overall value of the asset) is not shown. Plot data tables only give information on the land owner, and details of tenants can only be obtained from the computer. 8. To retire a total of 65 km of embankment in 10 CERP polders, a total of 236 ha of land will need to be acquired. Of this, 27 ha is khas (public) land, the remaining 209 ha consisting of 2,448 plots of private land owned or occupied by 1 ,148 households. On average the affected households lose 0.18 ha or about 1 1% of their land holdings. In many cases the value and productivity of their remaining land would increase due to the protection provided by the embankment. The total number of families rendered landless due to this land acquisition would be four (all earning their livelihood outside of agriculture). In addition to agricultural land, about 12% of PAPs would lose homestead land, 11% buildings, 2% shops or mills, 16% trees, 3% fishponds, and 1% salt beds. There is little sharecropping in the project area, but there are some longer term tenants. 9. The remaining land to be acquired under the project is similar to that surveyed above, except that in most cases the amount of land to be taken from any one PAP (e.g. for widening existing embankments) would be less. Compensation Policy 10. The policies and mechanisms developed in the RAP are primarily cash-based, with the exception of support for relocation of squatters (described in para 2 above). It is recognized that land-for-land compensation is not feasible nor desirable with the acquisition of long strips of land (right-of-way). Most farmers will lose only parts of their holdings and will prefer not to move, and cannot make use of land allocated by the Government somewhere else. The primary focus of the policy is therefore on adequate cash compensation. Within this framework, GOB has agreed to: (a) offer compensation for properties/assets based on their replacement value; (b) include compensation and assistance to affected non-property owners; (c) compensate for relocation costs; and (d) provide compensation for temporary loss of income. These provisions meet the requirements of Operational Directive 4.30 with respect to resettlement and rehabilitation.
 - 182 -ANNEX9 Page 4 of 6 11. The following types of losses are recognized under the compensation and resettlement policy: (a) agricultural or commercial land, including usufruct rights existing for more than one year; (b) homestead land; (c) standing crop; (d) living quarters or other physical structures (including buildings used for commercial or industrial activities); (e) trees or fish ponds; (f) income from displaced commercial or industrial activities; (g) regular wage income; and (h) occupied homestead land (either unauthorized use of Government land or use of private land with owner's permission). 12. Definition of the persons recognized as having these losses (i.e., entitled persons), level/form of compensation and assistance offered, and specific guidelines for calculating compensation are presented in the compensation and resettlement policy in the RAP (see attachment.) The policy commitments and institutional arrangements reflected in this policy matrix will be translated into Bangla and distributed to the affected people during joint verification. In addition, local level information meetings will be arranged where the text of the Bangla brochure will be explained publicly, both to the PAPs and to the implementing functionaries at the field level. The concerned BWDB staff will request the Union Council Chairmen to convene such meetings. Institutional Arrangements 13. Land and other properties will be acquired under the Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982. Under this Ordinance, the Deputy Commissioner's (DC's) office is the acquiring body acting on behalf of the implementing agency (in this case BWDB). The ordinance specifies that in determining the market value of property, the DC shall take into account the average value of similar properties in the vicinity sold during the preceding twelve months. Since such values are frequently understated for tax avoidance reasons, the compensation values resulting from these computations of recorded market prices were normally below the real market values of the property. In consideration of this problems, the Ordinance was amended in September 1993 to raise the premium on the calculated market value of property "in consideration of the compulsory nature of the acquisition" from 20% to 50%. Notwithstanding the increase in the premiums over recorded values, compensation for property based on computed values could still, in some cases, be less than replacement value. In addition, the ordinance does not fully cover all categories of loss by PAPs. The excess of entitlements in the agreed matrix over what is paid by the DCs would be financed from the project budget.

 - 185 - Annex 10 Page 1 of 14 BANGLADESH COASTAL EMBANKMENT REHABILITATION PROJECT Environmental Analysis A. Introduction 1. An environmental assessment of the Coastal Embankment Rehabilitation Project (CERP) was undertaken by environmental consultants financed by the European Commission. The report concluded that the overall environmental impact of the project is positive. The expected impacts on agriculture, fisheries, and the socio-economic status of the population in the project area will be significantly positive in most respects. The consultants concluded that there is adequate scope for mitigation of virtually all the identified adverse environmental and social impacts of the project and recommended mitigating measures and arrangements for impact monitoring. This environmental annex summarizes the consultants' main findings. B. Potential Environmental Impacts 2. The potential environmental impacts were considered and likely impacts were then characterized in terms of their scope, duration, probability of occurrence, significance and other appropriate factors. An attempt to characterize project impacts is summarized in Table 1. Since many of the potential positive and negative impacts are inter-related, could occur simultaneously amongst differing social groups and to a certain extent, negate each other, they were grouped and considered under the following headings: Agriculture. Fisheries. Socio-economics. Miscellaneous. This will allow a greater appreciation of the relative environmental costs and benefits of the project. Agriculture 3. Two of the greatest constraints on agriculture in the coastal strip are the salinisation of soil and flood damage due to incursion of saline and tidal fresh waters. One of the main aims of the project is to offer greater protection to coastal areas from high tide levels and cyclone surges. In the post-construction years one would expect to see a decline in soil salinity and flood recurrence and intensity. This would result in an increase in the farmers confidence that investments in agriculture will be secure. It is widely expected that these changes will manifest themselves as agricultural intensification and increases in yields and incomes.

 - 188 - Annex 10 Page 4 of 14 4. Predictions of the changes that will occur in cropping patterns have been made by the project preparation consultants and reviewed by the IDA appraisal mission. Generally, it appears that the percentage of cropped area under single cropping will decline and the area that is double cropped will increase. It is not likely that the area which is triple cropped will increase substantially. It is estimated that over a period of five years from completion of civil works, between 20% and 40% of the current T. Aman area would shift to HYV in the Kharif season. Conversion would be at the high end of the range in those polders with comparatively low levels of absentee ownership and share cropping. During the rabi season, however, HYV boro cultivation is expected to increase in only one polder due to the lack of fresh water for irrigation in other areas. 5. The sources of environmental impact which are generally associated with agricultural intensification are as follows: Increased use of agrochemicals. Depletion of existing surface water resources within polders for supplementary irrigation. Increased use of improved seed varieties and the abandonment of traditional local varieties. Increased Use of Agrochemicals 6. Intensification of agriculture is usually accompanied by increased use of fertilizers and pesticides which may pollute surface waters by runoff from soils and contaminate groundwater and aquifer bodies due to the downward percolation of polluted soil water. 7. Bangladesh has a comparatively low rate of fertilizer and pesticide consumption compared to neighboring countries. Currently the rate of agrochemical use in the coastal area is low. In other areas, where irrigated agriculture has been introduced, the consumption of fertilizers and pesticides has increased two to three fold. Much of this increased consumption is the result of boro cultivation with HYV rice which has a greater demand for nutrients than low yielding varieties and is also more prone to pests. S. It is unlikely that agrochemical consumption will increase dramatically in coastal polders or that environmental problems will arise for the following reasons: Due to lack of irrigation water it is not expected that triple cropping or the adoption of high yield boro varieties will be widespread. Switching to HYV varieties would be confined in most areas to the aman season. Therefore, one would not expect the agrochemical consumption rate to increase as much as two fold. The build-up of unacceptable levels of agrochemicals within polders is unlikely to occur due to the flushing effects of seasonal flooding and drainage of polders.
 - 189 - Annex 10 Page 5 of 14 Many of the coastal aquifers are small and isolated and 'protected' by the impermeability of the confining layers; widespread contamination by pesticides is therefore difficult to envisage. Supplementary Irrigation using Surface Water Resources 9. In many polder areas intensification of agricultural production leads to drawing down of surface water in ponds and khals, reducing water availability for domestic use, for bathing and laundry, for livestock watering and for fishing. While in the proposed project area there is some potential for this occurring, it should be remembered that the project would increase availability of fresh surface water, since in the absence of the project these water bodies would become saline. Over the longer run encouragement of crops requiring less water than rice will reduce this problem. Salinization of groundwater 10. While over-pumping leading to salinization of groundwater would have significant detrimental effects, it is unlikely to occur. Since any over-pumping would cause salinization of farmers' own sources of drinking water, they can be relied upon to use appropriate restraint, as they have in the past. Soil Waterlogging 11. One of the adverse impacts reported of the previous coastal embankment project was that waterlogging of soils occurred in some areas as a result of inadequate polder drainage. In general, this appears to have been addressed by polder drainage improvement schemes. The rehabilitation of embankments will result in their height being increased which could exacerbate or create such problems. However, since the environmental consultants are not aware of any significant waterlogging problems at present which are attributable to coastal embankments per se, it is not considered that this impact has a high probability of occurrence or significance. Further, the project will finance additional drainage improvements in selected polders which will help to prevent this impact from occurring. Abandonment of Local Seed Varieties 12. As the residual salinity of the soil declines due to the flushing effects of yearly flooding and drainage, farmers are expected to replace local salt tolerant varieties with HYV strains. While the impact at the farm level is expected to be a positive, measures are required to conserve the country's genetic resources. This is being undertaken under an ongoing IDA financed project (as described in para 31). 13. An additional impact related to the adoption of HYV rice is the potential reduction in fodder availability. This arises because the residual straw after rice harvesting is much less with HYV rice than with local varieties. Whilst this impact may be of local significance, we do not
 - 190 - Annex 10 Page 6 of 14 anticipate that it will be of significance throughout most of the project area. Where it is an issue, farmers can be encouraged to grow sufficient fodder crops to provide for livestock needs. Costs and Benefits 14. The overall impact of agricultural intensification can be determined by comparing the positive and negative impacts associated with intensification which are described above. The key negative impacts which have to be weighed against agricultural intensification are the loss of genetic diversity and the possibilities of pollution due to increased use of agrochemicals or depletion of surface water resources as a result of increased profitability of irrigation. It is difficult to compare these impacts on a quantitative basis with the benefits of increased crop yields. A more central issue to the cost-benefit analysis however, is the scope and cost for impact mitigation and the significance of any residual impacts. It is possible to collect and preserve for future use indigenous seed (a component of the World Bank/ODA Agriculture Support Services Project addresses this issue). It is also possible to encourage farmers to plant crops of lower water demand and to train farmers to use appropriate levels of agricultural inputs and integrated pest management methods. Fisheries 15. The construction of coastal embankments affects the fisheries sector in two ways. Open water capture fisheries are most likely to be adversely affected due to the barrier effect of the embankments. In contrast, embankment construction and the protection it affords will create a relatively risk-free environment for investments in intensive aquaculture to take place. Open Water Capture Fisheries 16. Generally inland fisheries have been in decline for some time. The reason for this is not clear-cut and is likely to involve a combination of factors in different areas, including overfishing and the development of flood control, drainage and irrigation systems. However, open fresh water fisheries are not of great biological or economic significance in the coastal polders where marine subsistence and economic fishing predominate. Moreover, the project embankments do not close up major or medium rivers or shoot channels of these rivers which are the main routes for migration of fish to the spawning grounds in flood plains. Therefore, it is unlikely that the CERP will have any significant discernable impacts on the open water capture fishery which are additional to existing pressures on the fishery. Aquaculture 17. Aquaculture production in the coastal areas of Bangladesh is well below potential rates of production. With a greater degree of protection, investments in both brackish and freshwater aquaculture could yield significant increases in fish and shrimp production.
 - 191 - Annex 10 Page 7 of 14 Freshwater Aquaculture 18. Estimates have been made of the area of cultivable and derelict ponds which could be rehabilitated, and of the approximate production of existing cultured ponds. Increased production benefits in existing cultured ponds will accrue to the owner or leaser rather than to the population in general. There may be some limited additional employment opportunities for the underemployed, however. There is considerable potential for involving the rural poor in reclaiming derelict ponds for freshwater fish and shrimp culture with the assistance of NGOs. This could have significant positive impacts on the nutritional and economic status of people involved, bringing project benefits to a wider section of the rural community. Brackish Water Aquaculture 19. It is highly probable that the project will result in an increase in the production of existing brackish water shrimp and fish farms, and also an increase in the area under aquaculture activities. The net result will be increased income to farm owners, increased employment opportunities and stimulation of support activities such as product processing and packaging, refrigeration services and transport. 20. In most of the project area shrimp is grown in alternation with salt production in areas unsuitable for rice. However, there is currently some conflict of interest with rice farmers in areas where both activities co- exist. It has been reported in some areas that shrimp farmers are forcing rice farmers to yield their land for expansion. Even in areas where this does not occur, salinisation of agricultural land adjacent to aquaculture farms is an interference factor. This issue predates the proposed project and is unlikely to be significantly worsened by the project. Costs and Benefits 21. While the damage to open water fisheries of flood control and drainage projects can be compensated in production terms by increases in aquaculture, it can generally be argued that the beneficiaries of increased aquaculture production are mainly richer elements of the rural communities while the loss of open water fisheries is mainly bourn by the poor. However, in the project area open water fisheries are not significant and the project does not adversely affect open water fisheries in other areas. Therefore, these general arguments do not apply in this case. While the main beneficiaries of expansion of acquacultural activities will still be the richer elements of the community, there will be increased employment opportunities without damage to the access of the poor to open water fisheries. Socio-Economic Impact 22. The CERP gives rise to several socio-economic impacts and issues which are related to the construction of embankments, agricultural and
 - 192 - Annex 10 Page 8 of 14 aquacultural intensification and to the afforestation component of the project. resettlement and compensation; improved economic status of the landless; and changes in the social fabric of rural communities. Resettlement and Compensation 23. The rehabilitation of embankments will require additional land on both the seaward and landward sides of the embankments. Some additional land may also be required for mangrove afforestation. This will affect existing land owners within the polders in the following ways: * Some homesteads which lie close to the existing embankments will have to be relocated. Homestead gardens, fruit trees and ponds may be lost due to land take. Agricultural land may be lost, affecting the families ability to sustain itself. Squatter families on embankments which require rehabilitation will have to be relocated. A detailed polder-wise survey of affected assets along the proposed embankment alignment and a resettlement and compensation plan are currently being undertaken to ensure that no persons are significantly adversely affected by the project. Provided the issue of compensation and resettlement is managed efficiently and effectively, only short term inconvenience, which could be deemed insignificant, may be experienced. Economic Status of the Landless 24. Some of the landless people currently living on the existing embankments or on char lands will receive the opportunity to lease embankment land which can be cultivated in suitable tree crops for the long term livelihood of the landless family. Landless Contracting Societies will also have the opportunity to undertake long term maintenance work for which they will receive payment. This income will substantially improve their economic status. The net result of successful afforestation and embankment leasing will have long-term significant positive impacts on the landless community. Social Fabric of Rural Communities 25. There is the potential for social conflicts to arise between the land owners who are affected by land take, and the newly settled landless who may occupy the area of the formers land. In addition, the social fabric of existing rural settlements may be disrupted by the resettlement of land owners elsewhere. Overall such impacts may not be significantly adverse. However,
 - 193 - Annex 10 Page 9 of 14 at the local level serious conflict could arise. This can largely be prevented by careful consideration during the planning stage and the involvement of beneficiaries. Costs and Benefits 26. At the gross project level, it is apparent that project benefits far outweigh the costs; one has to compare the loss of about 600 ha of land due to land take (requiring compensation payments to up to 6000 families or 60,000 people most of whom would lose only a small portion of their holdings) with the protection afforded to 1.2 million people. About 140,000 people were killed during the 1991 cyclone. 27. At the polder level, the positive impacts which arise from the CERP are of high significance for the landless and land owning groups of the project area. The enhanced opportunities for long and short term employment for landless and marginal farmers and the reduced potential for loss of life greatly outweigh, in opinion of the environmental consultants, the potential negative impacts of disruption to rural communities and hardship for land owners due to land take; there is considerable scope to prevent or mitigate these negative impacts. Hvdroloc*v and Sediment Dynamics 28. The construction of embankments alters the natural pattern of river flow and of seasonal flooding in the project area. However, the environmental consultants conclude that no significant adverse impacts will arise since there is ample scope to prevent or mitigate them. Afforestation 29. The provision of afforestation on the foreshore areas and on the embankments for protection of the embankments against wave action and erosion by rainwater and wind will have the following beneficial impacts upon the environment: Provide protection of the embankments and foreshore area against erosion by waves; Reduce the wind velocity of cyclones and strong monsoon winds and thereby reduce wind generated damages and soil erosion; Protect the pollen of the paddy from strong monsoon wind, resulting in increase of crop yields; Increase the vegetation coverage of the area which will facilitate restoration of the ecological imbalances and erratic behavior of the nature; Help meet the demand of fuel energy in the project area; and
 - 194 - Annex 10 Page 10 of 14 Provide valuable food, and cash income to the local farmers, resulting in uplift of the rural economy. This component would also provide a long-term means of livelihood to a significant number of landless families. C. Environmental Management Plan for the Project Area 30. Tables 1 and 2 summarize options for environmental monitoring and mitigation of project impacts. These options constitute an environmental management plan for the CERP and address the following requirements. * Monitoring of environmental impacts in a cost effective way and where possible combining the project monitoring requirements with those of related projects. Enhancement of the positive impacts of the project by providing assistance to beneficiaries in achieving sustainable development of polder resources through technical assistance and the development of self-help groups. Prevention and/or mitigation of negative impacts through improved polder management involving beneficiaries, agricultural extension activities and NGO guidance and assistance to beneficiaries. Management of Agricultural Intensification 31. The potential for negative environmental impacts of agricultural intensification to arise are directly related to the nature of cultivation practices in the project area. The Department of Agricultural Extension (DAE) and selected NGOs will, through extension activities, promote sustainable agricultural development. In particular, the IDA supported Agricultural Support Services Project (ASSP) will support: Integrated pest management. Appropriate application and handling of agrochemicals. Crop diversification (also involving lower water demand crops). Development of horticultural export businesses. Appropriate irrigation water management. In addition the ASSP will also support the development and cultivation of more appropriate seed varieties and the establishment of genetic seed banks.
