 - 197 - Annex 10 Page 13 of 14 32. Appropriate NGOs, who will be involved in other components of the project will be invited to collaborate in efforts to increase agricultural production and promote appropriate use of farm inputs. They will also play a role in assisting the landless in afforestation activities on the embankments and in foreshore areas. The DAE and the FD would provide technical support to the NGOs in these activities. Coordinating Development Efforts 33. To stimulate and coordinate the above activities an Agricultural Development Officer will be appointed to the Project Implementation Unit for a 10 month period spread over 18 months and starting in the second year of the project. The main duties of this officer would be to ensure that the necessary actions take place to promote agricultural intensification in the project area, many of which will be promoted nationally under the ASSP and NMIDP. He will collaborate with the ASSP and NMIDP PIU consultants, the CERP Social Development Officer, the CERP Environmental Specialist and other CERP TA specialists in ensuring that a holistic approach to the management of agricultural and environmental impacts is adopted. Management of Fisheries Issues 34. While the project will not obstruct any major natural water courses affecting fish migration, it could affect some small seasonal water bodies. In such areas, drainage structures would be operated so as to facilitate fisheries. The program for appropriate regulator operation would be developed by the environmental specialist in consultation with local groups and DoF staff at the upazila level. Shrimp inlets would be provided where needed to avoid damage to shrimp production. 35. Various on-going projects are involved in programs to promote fresh and brackish water fisheries production, particularly through the leasing of ponds, fish farm management and husbandry. The current project would increase the opportunities for such activities. Impact Monitoring 36. As noted in Table 2, much of the monitoring of the impact of the project can be achieved without additional work by drawing upon information already being collected by other agencies and donor-supported monitoring programs. The project implementation consultants terms of reference would include responsibility for developing appropriate monitoring programs, ensuring that working mechanisms are in place to obtain required data already being collected and supplementing this data as necessary. The technical assistance component of the proposed project includes funds for procurement of such supplementary equipment as many be appropriate, such as portable soil and water analysis kits. Data collected should be on a polder basis, to the extent possible, to allow information generated to be used for management decisions at the polder level.
 - 198 - Annex 10 Page 14 of 14 Polder Operation and Maintenance 37. The operation and management of polders will ultimately rest with the BWDB through its local offices. The BWDB will develop O&M schedules which take into account the agricultural and fisheries requirements of polder occupants. DAB and DoF would provide information on such requirements. The implementation consultants would assist in developing mechanisms at the local level to ensure that all concerned agencies are consulted. Developing BWDB's Environmental Management Capabilities 38. The BWDB is concerned with the development and management of a wide range of flood control, drainage and irrigation measures throughout Bangladesh. It is appropriate that an agency whose actions have far reaching consequences for the human and natural environment should incorporate environmental considerations into its activities. GOB is committed to developing environmental cells within all key Government agencies and Ministries. This approach is currently being defined within the GOB National Environmental Management Action Plan. 39. While this overall approach is being worked out, the current project will support short term in-country training on environmental and social issues for key technical, operational and management staff involved in the operation and maintenance of flood control, drainage, and irrigation structures and systems. This will help to develop social and environmental awareness within BWDB and encourage incorporation of environmental considerations in the planning and design of such projects.  - 199 - ANNEX 11 Page 1 of 5 BANGLADESH COASTAL EMBANKMENT REHABILITATION PROJECT (CERP) Economic Analysis 1. Economic analysis was done separately for 11 of 12 polders with major works financed under this project.1 Economic analysis was not done for those polders where the major works were financed under the PWP, and where the current project only includes complementary measures (minor works, afforestation and improved operation and maintenance (O&M)) because the return to such complementary works, treating the PWP investments as sunk costs, is known to be high. The main assumptions of the economic analysis follow. 2. Prices. All costs and benefits are expressed in constant 1994 prices. Recent Bank commodity price projections were used to derive world prices of traded goods. Economic farmgate prices were then calculated from the projected world prices for 2000/2005, with appropriate adjustments for quality, freight, insurance, handling, processing, and inland transport, as illustrated in Table 1. Import parity values are used for goods that are imported in normal years, such as wheat; export parity values are used for goods that Bangladesh normally exports, such as jute and urea. For non-traded goods and services, financial prices were converted to economic prices using a standard conversion factor (SCF) of 0.90. The official exchange rate of US$1 to Taka 40.25 (currently used for all projects in Bangladesh) converts prices in US dollars to Taka. Table 2 summarizes the financial and economic prices of the principal goods. Costs 3. Investment Costs. These include the cost of major and minor civil works: resectioning and/or retirement of embankments, replacement or repair of existing drainage structures, new drainage structures, new protection works, repairs to existing revetment works, surveys and investigations, khal re- excavation, and establishment costs, land acquisition, afforestation, and resettlement. All costs associated with these activities, minus price contingencies, taxes and duties, have been included. Sections of the embankments in polders 59/2 (Ramgati) and 72 (Sandwip) would have to be retired again in about year 15 of the operation due to erosion, and the costs 1. For Polder 60 (Sonagazi), the project does not include major civil works and only 2 km of embankment strengthening plus khal excavation, and this polder is therefore excluded from the economic analysis. More time is required to test the effectiveness of recently completed anti-erosion works before firm estimates can be justified. Anowar (where about US$2 million equivalent of expenditure is planned to complete major works started under PWP) is also excluded from the analysis.
 - 200 - ANNEX 11 Page 2 of 5 of retirement have accordingly been included. The salvage values of project facilities have not been subtracted from the costs because their discounted value would be very small. 4. Operation and Maintenance Costs. Incremental costs for O&M have been estimated for each polder with respect to protective works and routine and periodic maintenance, operation of structures, repair of cyclone damage, and maintenance of afforestation on embankment and the foreshore. The cost of family labor used in routine maintenance of the embankment and afforestation is assumed to be equal to the opportunity cost of labor; the latter is approximated by what laborers earn as casual workers or sharecroppers (about Taka 9,000 per family per year). Taxes and duties are excluded. 5. Value of Unskilled Labor. There are significant seasonal variations in agricultural wages in the project area and, because of widespread unemployment, market wages overstate the opportunity cost of labor. A weighted average wage rate for each polder was therefore applied to eliminate seasonal variations in farm wages. The average wage was then multiplied by 0.75 to reflect the true opportunity cost of labor. Benefits 6. The main benefits are reduction in loss of life and property during major cyclones, and prevention of salinity intrusions and storm surges during normal monsoons, allowing increased agricultural production. Production during normal monsoons would increase over the without project situation due to (i) the direct effects on yields due to reduced saline intrusions; (ii) the introduction of higher yielding crops made possible by the decrease in salinity and the reduced threat of periodic cyclone damage; and (iii) better drainage. In addition to these normal year benefits, there would be reduced agricultural losses in years of severe cyclones. Indirect benefits from growth linkages and environmental goods are excluded for lack of data. 7. Savincr of Human Life. No attempt has been made to quantify benefits from lives saved, but this is clearly a major benefit of the operation. B. Agricultural Benefits. Agricultural benefits include crop, livestock and fisheries production. (a) Crops. The components of incremental crop output during normal years are higher yields, more valuable cropping patterns and higher cropping intensity. The with and without project situations are estimated in Annex B. In estimating the reduction of damages during severe cyclones, it is assumed that high water levels corresponding to cyclones of a severity that occurs with a frequency of once in 40 years result in severe flooding both in the "without project" and "with project" situations. Hardly any standing crop would be saved. Estimation of benefits from protection to standing crops has therefore been based upon detailed analysis of damage from cyclone surges with 10 and 20 year return periods. Experience shows that about 50% and 40W of the crops would be saved by the embankments in the case of
 - 201 - ANNEX 11 Page 3 of 5 cyclonic surges with a return period of 10 and 20 years, respectively. (b) Livestock. Based on the official estimate of 40% of livestock lost in Sandwip (Polder 72) during the 1991 cyclone, a livestock loss of 309 in the "Without Project" situation has been assumed in the analysis for cyclones with a return period of 10 years or more. (c) Fisheries. Shrimp farming is an important activity in parts of the project zone. Improved embankments and sluices would protect fish ponds and shrimp farms, especially for cyclones with a return period of less than 40 years. The expected loss in income from such fisheries without the protection afforded by the project has been based on official estimates. 9. Salt Production. Salt production is vulnerable to saline intrusion at the end of the production period in April. Cyclone seasons are October- November and April-May, implying a 25% probability of an April cyclone. The probability of cyclone damage to salt production has accordingly been adjusted by a factor of 0.25 when estimating losses. 10. Protection of Property and Infrastructure. The embankments would protect houses and other buildings, roads, culverts and other structures. The damage during cyclones of a return period of 10 years or more was estimated based on data on damage during recent cyclones. About 864,000 houses were completely destroyed and another 774,000 were partially damaged during the 1991 cyclone. A value of Taka 15,000 has been assigned to each destroyed house. This low value is due to the fact that cyclones destroy mainly the poorest houses. The average damage to roads and culverts, based on field observations, is assumed to be 5% and 30%, respectively, of the replacement value. Based on a sample of four polders where road categories and number of culverts have been registered and valued, the average losses have been estimated at Tk 2,000 per ha. It has also been assumed that regulators and other infrastructure in shrimp farms would be saved particularly with regard to cyclones with return periods of 10 and 20 years. 11. Destruction by high winds has been excluded because the embankments do not protect against wind. Half of the damage to buildings has been attributed to wind, as have all losses of telephone lines and power supplies. 12. Afforestation Benefits. Afforestation of the embankments and a 50 to 200 meter wide belt on the foreshore would reduce cyclone damage and embankment maintenance costs. This benefit has been taken into account when estimating the costs of periodic and routine maintenance of the embankment and cyclone damage repairs. In addition to protecting the embankments, resulting in lower operations and maintenance costs, other direct economic benefits of afforestation include timber, fuel wood, fruits, and fodder. On the negative side, the foreshore afforestation would lead to loss of some agricultural land leading to reduced agricultural production. This loss has been assumed to be equal to the value added of T. Aman under saline conditions. (On only about 1,000 ha out of the 4,700 ha planned for foreshore afforestation are crops currently growtn.) Indirect environmental benefits have not been included for lack of data.
 - 202 - ANNEX 11 Page 4 of 5 Proiect Execution 13. Investment phasing will vary from polder to polder, depending on the condition of the embankment and the earthworks involved. The earthworks for the major embankment repairs are assumed to be completed within three years while the minor works component (other than khal re-excavation) would be completed in four years. Afforestation on the foreshore would start at the end of year one. Afforestation of the embankments would begin generally in year three, while starting in year two in a few polders. Project implementation has been assumed to produce full benefits beginning in the seventh year. 14. Summary of Results. Table 3 summarizes the aggregate results and information for individual polders is in Tables 4 to 14. The overall economic rate of return (ERR) based upon quantifyable benefits for the 11 polders in the project including major works, but excluding any value for reduced loss of human life, is estimated at 19.2%. The net present value of the incremental benefits is estimated at US$27.0 million. Polderwise ERRs range from 6.6% (Polder 70, Matherbari) to 28.1% (Polder 35/1, Sharankhola and Polder 59/3B Sudharam). All polders have ERRs greater than 12%, excepting Polders 48, 59/2, and 70 which have ERRs of about 7.9%, 6.9%, and 6.6%, respectively. Taking account of the additional benefit of saving human lives, these polders are considered justified for inclusion in the project. For example, during the 1991 cyclone about 10,000 people were killed in polder 70 from a population of 23,000. 15. Risks and Sensitivity Analysis. The economic analysis was supplemented by a sensitivity analysis to include higher investment and O&M costs and lower quantifiable benefits (agricultural, non-agricultural, and afforestation). (a) The effect of an increase in investment cost was tested because there is a risk of implementation delays due to management/institutional weaknesses and to inadequate Government funding resulting in cost escalation. (b) O&M costs may also increase. The proposed community participation in routine embankment maintenance and afforestation has not been tried in the proposed form. If the proposed afforestation component fails, the cost of routine maintenance would increase substantially. (c) The impact of a reduction in agricultural benefits was tested because this is the most important variable among the quantifiable benefits. Agricultural benefits would fall due to intrusion of saline water. A major risk of the project is that the life of the embankments may be reduced if inadequate funds are provided for O&M. In this case, non-agricultural benefits (protection of property and infrastructure), which are important in some polders, would also be affected adversely. In the event that the life of the embankments is reduced, available engineering data suggest that it would be necessary to have major expenditure on embankment rehabilitation in about year 10 and again in year 27 after project completion. It has been assumed in the analysis that for the
 - 203 - ANNEX 11 Page 5 of 5 southern polders, which are very prone to cyclone damage, and polders in the south west about 75% and 50%, respectively, of the present cost of rehabilitation would be required in the tenth and twenty seventh year after project completion. (d) The impact of a reduction in afforestation benefits was tested because there is a major risk in the community participation component for afforestation and routine embankment maintenance. 16. Tables 4 to 14 present the sensitivity analysis. Exceptionally large adverse changes in the variables tested would have to take place before the ERR for any of the polders, except Polders 48, 59/2, and 70, drops to 12%. Excluding Polders 48, 59/2 and 70, investment and O&M costs would have to increase by between 47% (Polder 73/1A&B, Hatiya) and 174% (Polder 59/3B, Sudharam) to bring ERR to 12%. Total project benefits would have to fall by between 32% (Polder 73/1A&B) and 64% (Polder 59/3B) to reduce ERR to 12%; in the case of agricultural benefits the required fall would range from 44% (Polder 73/1A&B, Hatiya) to 82% (Polder 72); for afforestation benefits the necessary fall would range from 202% (Polder 73/A&B) to 931% (Polder 35/1); and for a reduction in non-agricultural benefits the range would be from 390% (Polders 40/2, Patherghata and 59/3C, Companiganj) to 978% (Polder 35/1). The ERR is highly insensitive to changes in non-agricultural benefits because the value of non-agricultural benefits is relatively small in most of the polders. Major expenditure on embankment rehabilitation in year 10 and 27 after project completion (a proxy for cost effects of inadequate maintenance) would reduce the average ERR from 18.2* to 17.1%. 17. The table below gives the ERR for various combinations of unfavorable developments. It shows that to bring the ERR on quantifiable benefits below 12% would require a combination of a two year delay in project completion and a decrease in project benefits exceeding 30%, or a three year delay in project completion and a decrease in project benefits of about 20%. Other combinations which would reduce the ERR to 12% woud include a two year delay in project completion and an increase in O&M costs of over 30%, or a three year delay and an increase in O&M costs of about 15%. Such combinations of unfavorable developments are considered unlikely. Even then, the additional nonquantifyable benefits of saving human lives would still make the project worth doing.  - 226 - ANNEX 13 Page 1 of 2 BANGLADESH COASTAL EMBANKMENTb REHABILITATION PROJ13CT (CERP) Reporting Reauirements and Performance Indicators 1. The following reports would be sent regularly to IDA: (a) six monthly reports within one month of the closing of the first and third quarters of each financial year. The report would include physical and financial progress and would follow the outlines given in para 2 below; (b) quarterly progress reports on the resettlement program, including the performance of families on afforestation of embankment slopes and routine maintenance and the performance of community groups on the foreshore afforestation program; (c) audited financial statement of the project, together with the auditor's report and opinion on the financial statement, and the auditor's separate opinion on SOEs, within nine months of the end of each fiscal year; and (d) the borrower's contribution (Section II) to the project Completion Report, within three months of the Borrower's receipt of Sections I and III from IDA. 2. The six monthly reports should provide sufficient information for the use of IDA supervision missions tentatively scheduled for August and February of each financial year. The outline suggested for the report would include: (a) The Executive Summary (b) Physical Progress. This para would contain information on the components: civil works, resettlement, afforestation and O&M. The achievements expected each year are detailed in the physical progress performance indicators attached to this annex. The report would include a tabulated statement giving the progress against the performance indicators. In addition the report would include the progress on preparatory activities for: (i) civil works construction such as designs for minor works, procurement of major and minor civil works, land acquisition for civil works construction inclusive of khal re-excavation; (ii) land acquisition for resettlement; (iii) temporary relocation of displaced families; and (iv) preparation of programs for resettlement, O&M and forestry including forestry nurseries and trials. The report would also include a brief discussion on progress of each component. Attachments to the report would include besides the tabulated statement on the performance indicators, the physical progress for

doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Coastal Embankment Rehabilitation & Reconstruction Project are: 1) cyclone protection; 2) improved agricultural production; and 3) introduction of improved technology and improved methods of embankment maintenance. The project includes the following components: 1) rehabilitation and improvements to 12 sea-facing embankments; 2) minor rehabilitation and improvements to the non-coastal sections of the polders in the Mid-Term Program; 3) afforestation of embankment slopes and a strip of 50 to 200 meters of foreshore to reduce cyclone damage and embankment maintenance costs; 4) improved operation-maintenance of all polders in the Mid-Term Program; 5) a program of compensation, rehabilitation and resettlement of people displaced by the project; 6) environmental monitoring and provision for appropriate mitigating measures; 7) studies to investigate the possibility of cost-effective town protection works for Sandwip; 8) technical assistance for implementation support for components 1) through 7) above, and for coordination between the project and other projects concerning agricultural production and NGO activities; 9) training of staff of implementing agencies and participating NGOs, and for community participants; and 10) vehicles and minor equipment required for GOB supervision of project implementation, and for afforestation.
